**Sarajevo** ([/ˌsærəˈjeɪvoʊ/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*SARR-ə-YAY-voh*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"))^[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)^ is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city")^[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)^ and [largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "List of cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina") of [Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina"), with a population of 275,524 in its administrative limits.^[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)^^[\[4\]](#cite_note-bhas.ba-4)^ The [Sarajevo metropolitan area](/wiki/Sarajevo_metropolitan_area "Sarajevo metropolitan area") including [Sarajevo Canton](/wiki/Sarajevo_Canton "Sarajevo Canton"), [East Sarajevo](/wiki/Isto%C4%8Dno_Sarajevo "Istočno Sarajevo") and nearby municipalities is home to 555,210 inhabitants.^[\[a\]](#cite_note-8)^^[\[4\]](#cite_note-bhas.ba-4)^ Located within the greater Sarajevo valley of [Bosnia](/wiki/Bosnia_(region) "Bosnia (region)"), it is surrounded by the [Dinaric Alps](/wiki/Dinaric_Alps "Dinaric Alps") and situated along the [Miljacka](/wiki/Miljacka "Miljacka") River in the heart of the [Balkans](/wiki/Balkans "Balkans"), a region of [Southeastern Europe](/wiki/Southeastern_Europe "Southeastern Europe").{#cite_ref-bhas.ba_4-2}

Sarajevo is the political, financial, social, and cultural center of Bosnia and Herzegovina and a prominent center of culture in the Balkans. It exerts region-wide influence in entertainment, media, fashion, and the arts.^[\[8\]](#cite_note-9)^^[\[9\]](#cite_note-10)^ Due to its long history of religious and cultural diversity, Sarajevo is sometimes called the "[Jerusalem](/wiki/Jerusalem "Jerusalem") of Europe"^[\[1\]](#cite_note-In_Europe's_Jerusalem-1)^ or "Jerusalem of the Balkans".^[\[2\]](#cite_note-google27-2)^ It is one of a few major European cities to have a mosque, Catholic church, Eastern Orthodox church, and synagogue within the same neighborhood.^[\[10\]](#cite_note-11)^ It is also home to the former Yugoslavia's first institution of tertiary education in the form of an Islamic polytechnic, today part of the [University of Sarajevo](/wiki/University_of_Sarajevo "University of Sarajevo").^[\[11\]](#cite_note-12)^^[\[12\]](#cite_note-13)^{#cite_ref-13}

Although there is evidence of human settlement in the area since prehistoric times, the modern city arose in the 15th century as an [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") stronghold when the Ottoman empire extended into Europe.^[\[13\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEValerijanImamovićĆurovacKurto1997-14)^ Sarajevo has gained international renown several times throughout its history. In 1885, it was the first city in Europe and the second city in the world to have a full-time electric tram network running through the city, following [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco").^[\[14\]](#cite_note-amazon1-15)^{#cite_ref-amazon1_15-0}

In 1914, Sarajevo was the site of the [assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand](/wiki/Assassination_of_Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand "Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand") by a local [Young Bosnia](/wiki/Young_Bosnia "Young Bosnia") activist [Gavrilo Princip](/wiki/Gavrilo_Princip "Gavrilo Princip"), a murder that sparked [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"). This resulted in the end of [Austro-Hungarian](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary") rule in Bosnia and the creation of the multicultural [Kingdom of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia "Kingdom of Yugoslavia") in the Balkan region. Later, after [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), the area was designated the capital of the communist [Socialist Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Socialist Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina") within the [Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia"), leading to rapid expansion of its population and businesses with investment in infrastructure and economic development.

In 1984, Sarajevo hosted the [1984 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1984_Winter_Olympics "1984 Winter Olympics"), which marked a prosperous era for the city. However, after the start of the [Yugoslav Wars](/wiki/Yugoslav_Wars "Yugoslav Wars"), the city suffered the [longest siege of a capital city in the history of modern warfare](/wiki/Siege_of_Sarajevo "Siege of Sarajevo"), for a total of 1,425 days, from April 1992 to February 1996, during the [Bosnian War](/wiki/Bosnian_War "Bosnian War").

With continued [post-war reconstruction](/wiki/Architecture_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina#War-time_destruction_and_post-war_reconstruction "Architecture of Bosnia and Herzegovina") in the aftermath, Sarajevo is the [fastest growing city](/wiki/Economy_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Economy of Bosnia and Herzegovina") in Bosnia and Herzegovina.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-16)^ The travel guide series *[Lonely Planet](/wiki/Lonely_Planet "Lonely Planet")* ranked Sarajevo as the 43rd best city in the world.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-Lonely_Planet_2006-17)^ In December 2009, it recommended Sarajevo as one of the top ten cities to visit in 2010.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-News.com.au-18)^{#cite_ref-News.com.au_18-0}

In 2011, Sarajevo was nominated as the 2014 [European Capital of Culture](/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture "European Capital of Culture"). It was selected to host the [European Youth Olympic Festival](/wiki/2019_European_Youth_Olympic_Winter_Festival "2019 European Youth Olympic Winter Festival").^[\[18\]](#cite_note-19)^^[\[19\]](#cite_note-20)^ In addition, in October 2019, Sarajevo was designated as a [UNESCO Creative City](/wiki/Creative_Cities_Network "Creative Cities Network") for having placed culture at the center of its development strategies.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-21)^^[\[21\]](#cite_note-22)^ It is also ranked as one of the world's eighteen [Cities of Film](/wiki/City_of_Film "City of Film").^[\[22\]](#cite_note-23)^{#cite_ref-23}  

Etymology {#Etymology}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Etymology")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Sarajevo_Night_Skyline_Bosnia_%26_Herzegovina_2014_%2815510458883%29.jpg/220px-Sarajevo_Night_Skyline_Bosnia_%26_Herzegovina_2014_%2815510458883%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Night_Skyline_Bosnia_%26_Herzegovina_2014_(15510458883).jpg) Sarajevo at night

The name *Sarajevo* derives from the Turkish noun *saray*, meaning "palace" or "mansion" (from [Persian](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language") *sarāy*, سرای, of the same meaning). Scholars disagree on the origin of the *evo* attached to the end. In Slavic languages, the addition of "[evo](https://en.m.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Suffixes_-evo,_-ova_and_-ovo#:~:text=The%20suffixes%20%2Dovo%20and%20%2Devo,omitted%20in%20the%20toponym%20itself.)" may indicate a possessive noun, thereby making the name of Sarajevo 'city of the palace'.

One theory is that the name may have been derived from the [Ottoman Turkish](/wiki/Ottoman_Turkish "Ottoman Turkish") term *saray ovası*, first recorded in 1455,^[\[23\]](#cite_note-24)^ meaning "the plains around the palace" or simply "palace plains".^[\[24\]](#cite_note-25)^{#cite_ref-25}

However, in his *Dictionary of Turkish Loanwords* , [Abdulah Škaljić](https://sr.m.wikipedia.org/sr/%D0%90%D0%B1%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%85_%D0%A8%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%99%D0%B8%D1%9B) maintains that the *evo* ending is more likely to have come from the widespread [Slavic](/wiki/Slavic_languages "Slavic languages") suffix *[evo](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Suffixes_-evo,_-ova_and_-ovo "wikt:Appendix:Suffixes -evo, -ova and -ovo")* used to indicate place names, than from the Turkish ending *ova*.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-26)^ The first mention of the name Sarajevo was in a 1507 letter written by [Firuz Bey](/wiki/Firuz_Bey "Firuz Bey").^[\[26\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETanzerLongoria2007272-27)^ The official name during the [400 years of Ottoman rule](/wiki/Ottoman_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Ottoman Bosnia and Herzegovina") was *Saraybosna* ("Palace of Bosnia"), which remains the city's name in Modern Turkish.{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTETanzerLongoria2007272_27-0}

Sarajevo has had many nicknames. The earliest is *Šeher*, the term [Isa-Beg Ishaković](/wiki/Isa-Beg_Ishakovi%C4%87 "Isa-Beg Ishaković") used to describe the town he was going to construct---which is Turkish for "city" (*şehir*), in turn coming from the Persian *shahr* (شهر, meaning "city"). As Sarajevo developed, numerous nicknames came from comparisons to other cities in the Islamic world, i.e. "[Damascus](/wiki/Damascus "Damascus") of the North" and "European Jerusalem"; the latter being the most popular.  

Environment {#Environment}
--------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Environment")\]  

### Geography {#Geography}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Geography")\]

Sarajevo is near the geometric center of the triangular-shaped [Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina") and within the historical region of [Bosnia proper](/wiki/Bosnia_(region) "Bosnia (region)"). It is situated 518 m (1,699 ft) [above sea level](/wiki/Height_above_sea_level "Height above sea level") and lies in the Sarajevo valley, in the middle of the [Dinaric Alps](/wiki/Dinaric_Alps "Dinaric Alps").^[\[27\]](#cite_note-28)^{#cite_ref-28}

The valley was once an expansive, fertile, and green space, but considerable urban expansion and development took place following World War II. Forested hills and five major mountains surround the city. The highest of the surrounding peaks is [Treskavica](/wiki/Treskavica "Treskavica") at 2,088 m (6,850 ft), followed by [Bjelašnica](/wiki/Bjela%C5%A1nica "Bjelašnica") mountain at 2,067 m (6,781 ft), [Jahorina](/wiki/Jahorina "Jahorina") at 1,913 m (6,276 ft), [Trebević](/wiki/Trebevi%C4%87 "Trebević") at 1,627 m (5,338 ft), and [Igman](/wiki/Igman "Igman") the shortest at 1,502 m (4,928 ft). The last four are also known as the Olympic Mountains of Sarajevo.

When the city hosted the [1984 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1984_Winter_Olympics "1984 Winter Olympics"), venues were constructed at these mountains for many winter sports events. The city is developed within hilly terrain; some steeply inclined streets and residences perch on the hillsides.

The [Miljacka](/wiki/Miljacka "Miljacka") river is one of the city's chief geographic features. It flows through the city from east through the center of Sarajevo to the west part of the city, where it eventually meets up with the [Bosna](/wiki/Bosna_(river) "Bosna (river)") river. Miljacka River is also known as "The Sarajevo River". Its source (*Vrelo Miljacke* ) is 2 km (1.2 mi) south of the town of [Pale](/wiki/Pale,_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Pale, Bosnia and Herzegovina")^[\[28\]](#cite_note-29)^ at the foothills of Mount Jahorina, several kilometers to the east of Sarajevo center. The Bosna's source, [Vrelo Bosne](/wiki/Vrelo_Bosne "Vrelo Bosne") near [Ilidža](/wiki/Ilid%C5%BEa "Ilidža") (west Sarajevo), is another notable natural landmark and a popular destination for Sarajevans and other tourists. Several smaller rivers and streams, such as [Koševski Potok](/wiki/Ko%C5%A1evski_Potok "Koševski Potok"), also run through the city and its vicinity.{#cite_ref-29}  

### Cityscape {#Cityscape}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Cityscape")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Sarajevo_%E2%80%93_Iftar_at_%C5%BDuta_tabija.jpg/220px-Sarajevo_%E2%80%93_Iftar_at_%C5%BDuta_tabija.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_%E2%80%93_Iftar_at_%C5%BDuta_tabija.jpg) View of Sarajevo from a popular [Yellow Bastion](/wiki/%C5%BDuta_Tabija "Žuta Tabija") lookout

Sarajevo is close to the center of the triangular shape of Bosnia and Herzegovina in southeastern Europe. The Sarajevo city consists of four municipalities: [Centar](/wiki/Centar,_Sarajevo "Centar, Sarajevo") (Center), [Novi Grad](/wiki/Novi_Grad,_Sarajevo "Novi Grad, Sarajevo") (New Town), [Novo Sarajevo](/wiki/Novo_Sarajevo "Novo Sarajevo") (New Sarajevo), and [Stari Grad](/wiki/Stari_Grad,_Sarajevo "Stari Grad, Sarajevo") (Old Town), while the [Sarajevo metropolitan area](/wiki/Sarajevo_metropolitan_area "Sarajevo metropolitan area") (Greater Sarajevo area) includes these and the neighboring municipalities of [Ilidža](/wiki/Ilid%C5%BEa "Ilidža"), [Hadžići](/wiki/Had%C5%BEi%C4%87i "Hadžići"), [Vogošća](/wiki/Vogo%C5%A1%C4%87a "Vogošća") and [Ilijaš](/wiki/Ilija%C5%A1 "Ilijaš").

The Metropolitan area was reduced in the 1990s after the war and the [Dayton-imposed administrative division](/wiki/Dayton_Agreement "Dayton Agreement") of the country, with several municipalities partitioned along the border of the newly recognized [Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Federation_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina") (FBiH) and [Republika Srpska](/wiki/Republika_Srpska "Republika Srpska") (RS), creating several new municipalities which together form the city of [Istočno Sarajevo](/wiki/Isto%C4%8Dno_Sarajevo "Istočno Sarajevo") in the Republika Srpska: [Istočna Ilidža](/wiki/Isto%C4%8Dna_Ilid%C5%BEa "Istočna Ilidža"), [Istočno Novo Sarajevo](/wiki/Isto%C4%8Dno_Novo_Sarajevo "Istočno Novo Sarajevo"), [Istočni Stari Grad](/wiki/Isto%C4%8Dni_Stari_Grad "Istočni Stari Grad"), [Lukavica](/wiki/Lukavica_(Isto%C4%8Dno_Novo_Sarajevo) "Lukavica (Istočno Novo Sarajevo)"), [Pale (RS-section)](/wiki/Pale,_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Pale, Bosnia and Herzegovina"), and [Trnovo (RS-section)](/wiki/Trnovo,_Republika_Srpska "Trnovo, Republika Srpska"), along with the municipality of [Sokolac](/wiki/Sokolac "Sokolac") (which was not traditionally part of the Sarajevo area and was not partitioned).

The city has an urban area of 1,041.5 km^2^ (402.1 sq mi). Veliki Park (Great Park) is the largest green area in the center of Sarajevo. It is nestled between [Titova](/wiki/Marshal_Tito_street_(Sarajevo) "Marshal Tito street (Sarajevo)"), [Koševo](/wiki/Ko%C5%A1evo "Koševo"), [Džidžikovac](/wiki/D%C5%BEid%C5%BEikovac "Džidžikovac"), Tina Ujevića and Trampina Streets and in the lower part there is a monument dedicated to the Children of Sarajevo.  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Climate")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Sarajevo_Veliki-Park_2011-11-08.jpg/220px-Sarajevo_Veliki-Park_2011-11-08.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Veliki-Park_2011-11-08.jpg) Autumn in Sarajevo -- Veliki Park

Sarajevo has an [oceanic climate](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate") ([Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): **Cfb** ) bordering on a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") ([Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): **Dfb** ). Sarajevo's climate exhibits four seasons and uniformly spread precipitation. The proximity of the [Adriatic Sea](/wiki/Adriatic_Sea "Adriatic Sea") moderates Sarajevo's climate somewhat, although the mountains to the south of the city greatly reduce this maritime influence.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-Lacan-30)^ The average yearly temperature is 10 °C (50 °F), with January (−0.5 °C (31.1 °F) on average) being the coldest month of the year and July (19.7 °C (67.5 °F) on average) the warmest.{#cite_ref-Lacan_30-0}

The highest recorded temperature was 40.7 °C (105 °F) on 19 August 1946 and on 23 August 2008 (41.0), while the lowest recorded temperature was −26.2 °C (−15.2 °F) on 25 January 1942. On average, Sarajevo has seven days where the temperature exceeds 32 °C (89.6 °F) and four days where the temperature drops below −15 °C (5 °F) per year.^[\[30\]](#cite_note-weatherbase-31)^ The city typically experiences mildly cloudy skies, with an average yearly [cloud cover](/wiki/Cloud_cover "Cloud cover") of 45%.{#cite_ref-weatherbase_31-0}

The cloudiest month is December (75% average cloud cover), while the clearest is August (37%). Moderate precipitation occurs fairly consistently throughout the year, with an average 75 days of rainfall. Suitable climatic conditions have allowed [winter sports](/wiki/Winter_sports "Winter sports") to flourish in the region, as exemplified by the [1984 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1984_Winter_Olympics "1984 Winter Olympics") that were held in Sarajevo. Average winds are 28--48 km/h (17--30 mph) and the city has 1,769 hours of sunshine.  
{#cite_ref-WMO_32-0}{#cite_ref-NOAA_33-0}

### Air quality {#Air_quality}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Air quality")\]

[Air pollution](/wiki/Air_pollution "Air pollution") is a major issue in Sarajevo.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-34)^^[\[34\]](#cite_note-35)^ According to the 2016 [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization")'s Ambient Air Pollution Database,^[\[35\]](#cite_note-36)^ the annual average [PM2.5](/wiki/Particulates#Size,_shape_and_solubility_matter "Particulates") concentration in 2010 was estimated to be 30 μg/m^3^ based on PM10 measurement, which is 3 times higher than recommended by [WHO Air Quality Guidelines](/wiki/WHO_Air_Quality_Guideline "WHO Air Quality Guideline")^[\[36\]](#cite_note-37)^ for the annual average PM2.5. There are no recent direct long-term PM2.5 measurements available in Sarajevo and only estimates can be made from PM10, which is less health-relevant than PM2.5.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-38)^ Real-time air quality data in the form of PM10, ozone, [NO~2~](/wiki/Nitrogen_dioxide "Nitrogen dioxide"), [CO](/wiki/Carbon_monoxide "Carbon monoxide") and [SO~2~](/wiki/Sulfur_dioxide "Sulfur dioxide") by the [Federal Hydrometeorological Institute](http://www.fhmzbih.gov.ba/latinica/ZRAK/vrijednostiPolutanata.php) [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20180913190025/http://www.fhmzbih.gov.ba/latinica/ZRAK/vrijednostiPolutanata.php) 13 September 2018 at the [Wayback Machine](/wiki/Wayback_Machine "Wayback Machine").^[\[38\]](#cite_note-39)^{#cite_ref-39}

### Ancient times {#Ancient_times}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Ancient times")\]  
Main article: [Stari Grad, Sarajevo](/wiki/Stari_Grad,_Sarajevo "Stari Grad, Sarajevo")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Butmirska_vaza.jpg/220px-Butmirska_vaza.jpg)](/wiki/File:Butmirska_vaza.jpg) [Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic") period [Butmir](/wiki/Butmir_culture "Butmir culture") vase

One of the earliest findings of settlement in the Sarajevo area is that of the Neolithic [Butmir culture](/wiki/Butmir_culture "Butmir culture"). The discoveries at [Butmir](/wiki/Butmir "Butmir") were made on the grounds of the modern-day Sarajevo suburb [Ilidža](/wiki/Ilid%C5%BEa "Ilidža") in 1893 by [Austro-Hungarian](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary") authorities during the construction of an agricultural school. The area's richness in [flint](/wiki/Flint "Flint") was attractive to Neolithic humans, and the settlement flourished. The settlement developed unique ceramics and pottery designs, which characterize the Butmir people as a unique culture, as described at the International Congress of Archaeologists and [Anthropologists](/wiki/Anthropology "Anthropology") meeting in Sarajevo in 1894.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-40)^{#cite_ref-40}

The next prominent culture in Sarajevo was the [Illyrians](/wiki/Illyrians "Illyrians"). The ancient people, who considered most of the [Western Balkans](/wiki/Balkans#Western_Balkans "Balkans") as their homeland, had several key settlements in the region, mostly around the river [Miljacka](/wiki/Miljacka "Miljacka") and the Sarajevo valley. The Illyrians in the Sarajevo region belonged to the *[Daesitiates](/wiki/Daesitiates "Daesitiates")* , the last Illyrian people in Bosnia and Herzegovina to resist [Roman](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome") occupation. Their defeat by the [Roman](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") emperor [Tiberius](/wiki/Tiberius "Tiberius") in 9 AD marks the start of Roman rule in the region. The Romans never built up the region of modern-day Bosnia, but the [Roman colony](/wiki/Colonies_in_antiquity "Colonies in antiquity") of Aquae Sulphurae was near the top of present-day Ilidža, and was the most important settlement of the time.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-41)^ After the Romans, the [Goths](/wiki/Goths "Goths") settled the area, followed by the [Slavs](/wiki/Slavs "Slavs") in the 7th century.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-Brit-42)^{#cite_ref-Brit_42-0}  

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Middle Ages")\]  
See also: [Sarajevo during the Middle Ages](/wiki/Sarajevo_during_the_Middle_Ages "Sarajevo during the Middle Ages")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Ilid%C5%BEa_Rimski_most_3.jpg/220px-Ilid%C5%BEa_Rimski_most_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ilid%C5%BEa_Rimski_most_3.jpg) [Roman bridge](/wiki/Roman_bridge_in_Ilid%C5%BEa "Roman bridge in Ilidža"), erected 1530 in [Ilidža](/wiki/Ilid%C5%BEa "Ilidža"), built of remnants of an old Roman settlement

During the [Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages"), Sarajevo was part of the Bosnian province of Vrhbosna near the traditional center of the [Kingdom of Bosnia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bosnia "Kingdom of Bosnia"). Though a city named *Vrhbosna* existed, the exact settlement in Sarajevo at this time is [debated](/wiki/History_of_Sarajevo#Middle_Ages "History of Sarajevo"). Various documents note a place called *Tornik* in the region, most likely in the area of the [Marijin Dvor](/wiki/Marijin_Dvor_(Sarajevo) "Marijin Dvor (Sarajevo)") neighborhood. By all indications, Tornik was a very small marketplace surrounded by a proportionally small village and was not considered very important by [Ragusan](/wiki/Dubrovnik "Dubrovnik") merchants.

Other scholars say that *Vrhbosna* was a major town in the wider area of modern-day Sarajevo. [Papal](/wiki/Holy_See "Holy See") documents say that in 1238, a cathedral dedicated to [Saint Paul](/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle "Paul the Apostle") was built in the area. Disciples of the notable saints [Cyril](/wiki/Saints_Cyril_and_Methodius "Saints Cyril and Methodius") and [Methodius](/wiki/Saints_Cyril_and_Methodius "Saints Cyril and Methodius") stopped in the region, founding a church near [Vrelo Bosne](/wiki/Vrelo_Bosne "Vrelo Bosne"). Whether or not the town was somewhere in the area of modern-day Sarajevo, the documents attest to its and the region's importance. There was also a citadel [Hodidjed](/wiki/Hodidjed "Hodidjed") north-east to the [Old City](/wiki/Stari_Grad,_Sarajevo "Stari Grad, Sarajevo"), dating from around 1263 until it was occupied by the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") in 1429.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-43)^{#cite_ref-43}  

### Ottoman era {#Ottoman_era}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Ottoman era")\]  
See also: [Bosnia and Herzegovina cuisine](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_cuisine "Bosnia and Herzegovina cuisine"), [Ottoman Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Ottoman_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Ottoman Bosnia and Herzegovina"), and [Sacking of Sarajevo](/wiki/Sacking_of_Sarajevo "Sacking of Sarajevo")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Sarajevo_Bascarsija_Sebilj_2007-08-16_%287%29.jpg/220px-Sarajevo_Bascarsija_Sebilj_2007-08-16_%287%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Bascarsija_Sebilj_2007-08-16_(7).jpg) The [Sebilj](/wiki/Sebilj_in_Sarajevo "Sebilj in Sarajevo") is a [pseudo-Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") style wooden [fountain](/wiki/Fountain "Fountain") in the centre of [Baščaršija](/wiki/Ba%C5%A1%C4%8Dar%C5%A1ija "Baščaršija") square. The current structure is an 1891 reconstruction of the original, which burnt down in 1852

Sarajevo was founded by the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") in the 1450s upon its conquest of the region, with 1461 used as the city's founding date. The first Ottoman governor of [Bosnia](/wiki/Bosnia_Eyalet "Bosnia Eyalet"), [Isa-Beg Ishaković](/wiki/Isa-Beg_Ishakovi%C4%87 "Isa-Beg Ishaković"), transformed the cluster of villages into a city and state capital by building several key structures, including a mosque, a closed marketplace, a [hamam](/wiki/Hamam "Hamam"), a [caravansarai](/wiki/Caravansarai "Caravansarai"), a bridge, and of course the governor's palace ("Saray"), which gave the city its present name in conjunction with "evo", a derivative of "ova" meaning lowland. The mosque was named "Careva Džamija" (the [Emperor's Mosque](/wiki/Emperor%27s_Mosque "Emperor's Mosque")) in honor of Sultan [Mehmed II](/wiki/Mehmed_the_Conqueror "Mehmed the Conqueror"). With the improvements, Sarajevo quickly grew into the largest city in the region. By the [15th century](/wiki/15th_century "15th century") the settlement was established as a city, named *Bosna-Saraj*, around the citadel in 1461.

Following the [expulsion of Jews from Spain](/wiki/Expulsion_of_Jews_from_Spain "Expulsion of Jews from Spain") at the end of the 15th century, and the invitation from the Ottoman Empire to resettle their population, [Sephardic Jews](/wiki/Sephardi_Jews "Sephardi Jews") arrived in Sarajevo, which over time would become a leading center of Sephardic culture and the [Ladino language](/wiki/Judaeo-Spanish "Judaeo-Spanish"). Though relatively small in size, a Jewish quarter would develop over several blocks in [Baščaršija](/wiki/Ba%C5%A1%C4%8Dar%C5%A1ija "Baščaršija").

Many local Christians converted to Islam at this time. To accommodate the new pilgrims on the road to [Mecca](/wiki/Mecca "Mecca"), in 1541, [Gazi Husrev-beg](/wiki/Gazi_Husrev-beg "Gazi Husrev-beg")'s quartermaster Vekil-Harrach built a pilgrim's mosque which it is still known to this day as the [Hadžijska Mosque](/wiki/Had%C5%BEijska_Mosque "Hadžijska Mosque").

Under leaders such as the second governor Gazi Husrev-beg, Sarajevo grew at a rapid rate. Husrev-beg greatly shaped the physical city, as most of what is now the Old Town was built during his reign. Sarajevo became known for its large marketplace and numerous mosques, which by the middle of the 16th century numbered more than 100. At the peak of the empire, Sarajevo was the biggest and most important Ottoman city in the Balkans after [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul").^[\[43\]](#cite_note-44)^ By 1660, the population of Sarajevo was estimated to be over 80,000.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-:0-45)^ By contrast, [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade") in 1683 had 100,000,^[\[45\]](#cite_note-The_History_of_Belgrade-46)^ and [Zagreb](/wiki/Zagreb "Zagreb") as late as 1851 had 14,000 people. As political conditions changed, Sarajevo became the site of warfare.{#cite_ref-The_History_of_Belgrade_46-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Impressions_of_Sarajevo_%282496832484%29.jpg/220px-Impressions_of_Sarajevo_%282496832484%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Impressions_of_Sarajevo_(2496832484).jpg) The [Sarajevo Clock Tower](/wiki/Sarajevo_Clock_Tower "Sarajevo Clock Tower") and [Gazi Husrev-beg Mosque](/wiki/Gazi_Husrev-beg_Mosque "Gazi Husrev-beg Mosque")

In 1697, during the [Great Turkish War](/wiki/Great_Turkish_War "Great Turkish War"), a raid was led by [Prince Eugene of Savoy](/wiki/Prince_Eugene_of_Savoy "Prince Eugene of Savoy") of the [Habsburg monarchy](/wiki/Habsburg_monarchy "Habsburg monarchy") against the Ottoman Empire, [which conquered Sarajevo and left it plague-infected and burned to the ground](/wiki/Sacking_of_Sarajevo "Sacking of Sarajevo"). After his men had looted thoroughly, they set the city on fire and destroyed nearly all of it in one day. Only a handful of neighborhoods, some mosques, and an [Orthodox church](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church") were left standing. Numerous other fires weakened the city, which was later rebuilt but never fully recovered from the destruction. By 1807, it had only some 60,000 residents.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-:0-45)^{#cite_ref-:0_45-1}

In the 1830s, several battles of the [Bosnian uprising](/wiki/Bosnian_uprising_(1831%E2%80%9332) "Bosnian uprising (1831–32)") had taken place around the city. These had been led by [Husein Gradaščević](/wiki/Husein_Grada%C5%A1%C4%8Devi%C4%87 "Husein Gradaščević"). Today, a major city street is named *Zmaj od Bosne* (Dragon of Bosnia) in his honor. The rebellion failed and for several more decades, the Ottoman state remained in control of Bosnia.

The Ottoman Empire made Sarajevo an important administrative center by 1850. [Baščaršija](/wiki/Ba%C5%A1%C4%8Dar%C5%A1ija "Baščaršija") became the central commercial district and cultural center of the city in the 15th century when Isa-Beg Ishaković founded the town.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-47)^ The toponym Baščaršija derives from the [Turkish language](/wiki/Turkish_language "Turkish language").{#cite_ref-47}  

### Austria-Hungary {#Austria-Hungary}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Austria-Hungary")\]  
See also: [Austro-Hungarian rule in Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_rule_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Austro-Hungarian rule in Bosnia and Herzegovina") and [Austro-Hungarian campaign in Bosnia and Herzegovina in 1878](/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_campaign_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_in_1878 "Austro-Hungarian campaign in Bosnia and Herzegovina in 1878")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Minutos_previos_al_atentado_en_Sarajevo.jpg/220px-Minutos_previos_al_atentado_en_Sarajevo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Minutos_previos_al_atentado_en_Sarajevo.jpg) [Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria](/wiki/Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria "Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria") arrives at [the city hall](/wiki/National_and_University_Library_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "National and University Library of Bosnia and Herzegovina") on the day of his assassination, 28 June 1914

[Austria-Hungary's occupation of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_rule_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Austro-Hungarian rule in Bosnia and Herzegovina") came in 1878 as part of the [Treaty of Berlin](/wiki/Treaty_of_Berlin_(1878) "Treaty of Berlin (1878)"), and [complete annexation](/wiki/Bosnian_Crisis "Bosnian Crisis") followed in 1908, angering the [Serbs](/wiki/Serbs_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Serbs of Bosnia and Herzegovina"). Sarajevo was industrialized by Austria-Hungary, who used the city as a testing area for new inventions such as [tramways](/wiki/Trams_in_Sarajevo "Trams in Sarajevo"), which were established in 1885 before they were later installed in [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"). Architects and engineers wanting to help rebuild Sarajevo as a modern European capital rushed to the city. A fire that burned down a large part of the central city area (*čaršija* ) left more room for redevelopment. As a result, the city has a unique blend of the remaining Ottoman city market and contemporary Western architecture. Sarajevo also has some examples of Secession- and Pseudo-[Moorish](/wiki/Moors "Moors") styles that date from this period.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Latin_Bridge_in_Sarajevo.jpg/220px-Latin_Bridge_in_Sarajevo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Latin_Bridge_in_Sarajevo.jpg) The [Latin Bridge](/wiki/Latin_Bridge "Latin Bridge") was the site of the [assassination of Franz Ferdinand](/wiki/Assassination_of_Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand "Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand")

The [Austro-Hungarian](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary") period was one of great development for the city, as the Western power brought its new acquisition up to the standards of the [Victorian age](/wiki/Victorian_era "Victorian era"). Various factories and other buildings were built at this time,^[\[47\]](#cite_note-48)^ and a large number of institutions were both Westernized and modernized. For the first time in history, Sarajevo's population began writing in [Latin script](/wiki/Latin_alphabet "Latin alphabet").^[\[41\]](#cite_note-Brit-42)^^[\[48\]](#cite_note-49)^ For the first time in centuries, the city significantly expanded outside its traditional borders. Much of the city's contemporary central municipality ([Centar](/wiki/Centar,_Sarajevo "Centar, Sarajevo")) was constructed during this period.{#cite_ref-49}

Architecture in Sarajevo quickly developed into a wide range of styles and buildings. The [Sacred Heart Cathedral](/wiki/Sarajevo_cathedral "Sarajevo cathedral"), for example, was constructed using elements of [neo-gothic](/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture "Gothic Revival architecture") and [Romanesque architecture](/wiki/Romanesque_architecture "Romanesque architecture"). The [National Museum](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina"), [Sarajevo brewery](/wiki/Sarajevska_pivara "Sarajevska pivara"), and [City Hall](/wiki/Vije%C4%87nica "Vijećnica") were also constructed during this period. Additionally, Austrian officials made Sarajevo the first city in this part of Europe to have a [tramway](/wiki/Tram "Tram").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Academy_of_fine_art_and_Festina_lente.jpg/220px-Academy_of_fine_art_and_Festina_lente.jpg)](/wiki/File:Academy_of_fine_art_and_Festina_lente.jpg) The [Academy of Fine Arts](/wiki/Academy_of_Fine_Arts_Sarajevo "Academy of Fine Arts Sarajevo") was originally built to serve as an [Evangelical Church](/wiki/Reformed_Church_in_Austria "Reformed Church in Austria") in 1899

Although the Bosnia Vilayet *[de jure](/wiki/De_jure "De jure")* remained part of the Ottoman Empire, it was *[de facto](/wiki/De_facto "De facto")* governed as an integral part of Austria-Hungary with the Ottomans having no say in its day-to-day governance. This lasted until 1908 when the territory was formally annexed and turned into a [condominium](/wiki/Condominium_(international_law) "Condominium (international law)"), jointly controlled by both Austrian [Cisleithania](/wiki/Cisleithania "Cisleithania") and Hungarian [Transleithania](/wiki/Lands_of_the_Crown_of_Saint_Stephen "Lands of the Crown of Saint Stephen").

The event that triggered [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") was the [assassination](/wiki/Assassination_of_Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand "Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand") of [Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria](/wiki/Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria "Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria"), along with his wife [Sophie, Duchess of Hohenberg](/wiki/Sophie,_Duchess_of_Hohenberg "Sophie, Duchess of Hohenberg") in Sarajevo on 28 June 1914 by [Gavrilo Princip](/wiki/Gavrilo_Princip "Gavrilo Princip"), a Bosnian Serb and self-declared Yugoslav, and member of [Young Bosnia](/wiki/Young_Bosnia "Young Bosnia").^[\[49\]](#cite_note-50)^ This was followed by the [Anti-Serb riots in Sarajevo](/wiki/Anti-Serb_riots_in_Sarajevo "Anti-Serb riots in Sarajevo"), which resulted in two deaths and destruction of property.{#cite_ref-50}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/MapSaraevo1932-1824.jpg/220px-MapSaraevo1932-1824.jpg)](/wiki/File:MapSaraevo1932-1824.jpg) Detailed plan of Sarajevo, 1932

In the ensuing war, however, most of the Balkan offensives occurred near Belgrade, and Sarajevo largely escaped damage and destruction. Following the war, Bosnia was annexed into the [Kingdom of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia "Kingdom of Yugoslavia"), and Sarajevo became the capital of the [Drina Province](/wiki/Drina_Banovina "Drina Banovina").  

### Yugoslavia {#Yugoslavia}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Yugoslavia")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Vjecna_vatra%2C_Sarajevo.jpg/220px-Vjecna_vatra%2C_Sarajevo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vjecna_vatra,_Sarajevo.jpg) The [Eternal flame](/wiki/Eternal_flame_(Sarajevo) "Eternal flame (Sarajevo)"), a memorial to the military and civilian victims of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") in Sarajevo

After World War I and pressure from the [Royal Serbian Army](/wiki/Royal_Serbian_Army "Royal Serbian Army"), alongside rebelling [Slavic](/wiki/Slavs "Slavs") nations in [Austria-Hungary](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary"), Sarajevo became part of the [Kingdom of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia "Kingdom of Yugoslavia"). Though it held some political significance as the center of first the Bosnian region and then the Drinska Banovina, the city was no longer a national capital and saw a decline in global influence.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-51)^{#cite_ref-51}

During [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), the Kingdom of Yugoslavia's army was overrun by German and Italian forces. Following a German bombing campaign, Sarajevo was captured on 15 April 1941 by the [16th Motorized Infantry Division](/wiki/16th_Infantry_Division_(Wehrmacht) "16th Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)"). The [Axis powers](/wiki/Axis_powers "Axis powers") created the [Independent State of Croatia](/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia "Independent State of Croatia") and included Sarajevo in its territory.

Immediately following the occupation, the main Sephardi Jewish synagogue, [Il Kal Grande](/wiki/Il_Kal_Grande "Il Kal Grande"), was looted, burned, and destroyed by the [Nazis](/wiki/Nazism "Nazism"). Within a matter of months, the centuries-old Sephardi and Ashkenazi Jewish communities of Sarajevo, comprising the vast majority of [Bosnian Jewry](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "History of the Jews in Bosnia and Herzegovina"), would be rounded up in the Old Synagogue (Stari hram) and deported to their deaths in [Croatian concentration camps](/wiki/Concentration_camps_in_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia "Concentration camps in the Independent State of Croatia"). Roughly 85% of Bosnia's Jewish population would perish at the hands of the Nazis and the [Ustaše](/wiki/Usta%C5%A1e "Ustaše") [during the Holocaust in the region](/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia "The Holocaust in the Independent State of Croatia"). The [Sarajevo Haggadah](/wiki/Sarajevo_Haggadah "Sarajevo Haggadah") was the most important artifact which survived this period, smuggled out of Sarajevo and saved from the Nazis and Ustaše by the chief librarian of the National Museum, [Derviš Korkut](/wiki/Dervi%C5%A1_Korkut "Derviš Korkut").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Sarajevo_Vraca_Spomen_Park_4.jpg/175px-Sarajevo_Vraca_Spomen_Park_4.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Vraca_Spomen_Park_4.jpg) [Vraca Memorial Park](/wiki/Vraca_Memorial_Park "Vraca Memorial Park") is a park dedicated to World War II victims in the city

On 12 October 1941, a group of 108 notable [Bosniak](/wiki/Bosniaks "Bosniaks") citizens of Sarajevo signed the [Resolution of Sarajevo Muslims](/wiki/Resolution_of_Sarajevo_Muslims "Resolution of Sarajevo Muslims") by which they condemned the [Genocide of Serbs](/wiki/Genocide_of_Serbs_in_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia "Genocide of Serbs in the Independent State of Croatia") organized by the Ustaše, made a distinction between the Bosniaks who participated in such persecutions and the rest of the Bosniak population, presented information about the persecutions of Bosniaks by Serbs, and requested security for all citizens of the country, regardless of their identity.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-52)^ During the summer of 1941, Ustaše militia periodically interned and executed groups of [Sarajevo Serbs](/wiki/Serbs_in_Sarajevo "Serbs in Sarajevo").^[\[52\]](#cite_note-Balić-53)^ In August 1941, they arrested about one hundred Serbs suspected of ties to the resistance armies, mostly church officials and members of the intelligentsia, and executed them or deported them to concentration camps.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-Balić-53)^ By mid-summer 1942, around 20,000 Serbs found refuge in Sarajevo from Ustaše terror.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGumz1998-54)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGumz1998_54-0}

The city was bombed by the [Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") from 1943 to 1944.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-55)^ The [Yugoslav Partisan](/wiki/Yugoslav_Partisans "Yugoslav Partisans") movement was represented in the city. In the period February--May 1945, [Maks Luburić](/wiki/Vjekoslav_Luburi%C4%87 "Vjekoslav Luburić") set up a Ustaše headquarters in a building known as [Villa Luburić](/wiki/Villa_Luburi%C4%87 "Villa Luburić") and used it as a torture and execution place whose 323 victims were identified after the war. The resistance was led by [Vladimir Perić Valter](/wiki/Vladimir_Peri%C4%87 "Vladimir Perić"), who died while leading the liberation of the city on 6 April 1945.{#cite_ref-55}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Sarajevo_Novo_Sarajevo.jpg/220px-Sarajevo_Novo_Sarajevo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Novo_Sarajevo.jpg) View west toward parts of [Novo Sarajevo](/wiki/Novo_Sarajevo "Novo Sarajevo")

After the war, Sarajevo was the capital of the [Socialist Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Socialist Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina") within the [Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia"). The Republic Government invested heavily in Sarajevo, building many new residential blocks in the municipalities of [Novi Grad](/wiki/Novi_Grad,_Sarajevo "Novi Grad, Sarajevo") and [Novo Sarajevo](/wiki/Novo_Sarajevo "Novo Sarajevo"), while simultaneously developing the city's industry and transforming Sarajevo into a modern city. Sarajevo grew rapidly as it became an important regional industrial center in Yugoslavia. Between the end of the war and the end of Yugoslavia, the city grew from a population of 115,000 to more than 600,000 people. The [Vraca Memorial Park](/wiki/Vraca_Memorial_Park "Vraca Memorial Park"), a monument for victims of World War II, was dedicated on 25 November, the "[Statehood Day of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Statehood_Day_(Bosnia_and_Herzegovina) "Statehood Day (Bosnia and Herzegovina)")" when the [ZAVNOBIH](/wiki/State_Anti-fascist_Council_for_the_National_Liberation_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "State Anti-fascist Council for the National Liberation of Bosnia and Herzegovina") held their first meeting in 1943.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-Donia-56)^{#cite_ref-Donia_56-0}

A crowning moment of Sarajevo's time in Socialist Yugoslavia was the [1984 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1984_Winter_Olympics "1984 Winter Olympics"). Sarajevo beat out [Sapporo](/wiki/Sapporo "Sapporo"), Japan, and [Falun](/wiki/Falun "Falun")/[Gothenburg](/wiki/Gothenburg "Gothenburg"), Sweden, to host the [Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games"). The games were followed by a tourism boom, making the 1980s one of the city's most prosperous decades.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-57)^{#cite_ref-57}  

### Bosnian War {#Bosnian_War}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Bosnian War")\]  
Main article: [Siege of Sarajevo](/wiki/Siege_of_Sarajevo "Siege of Sarajevo")  
See also: [Sniper Alley](/wiki/Sniper_Alley "Sniper Alley")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Sarajevo_Red_Line_3.jpeg/220px-Sarajevo_Red_Line_3.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Red_Line_3.jpeg) The [Sarajevo Red Line](/wiki/Sarajevo_Red_Line "Sarajevo Red Line"), a memorial event of the [Siege of Sarajevo](/wiki/Siege_of_Sarajevo "Siege of Sarajevo")'s 20th anniversary. 11,541 empty chairs symbolized 11,541 victims of the war who were killed during the Siege^[\[57\]](#cite_note-58)^^[\[58\]](#cite_note-59)^

The [Bosnian War](/wiki/Bosnian_War "Bosnian War") for independence resulted in large-scale destruction and dramatic population shifts during the [Siege of Sarajevo](/wiki/Siege_of_Sarajevo "Siege of Sarajevo") between 1992 and 1996. Thousands of Sarajevans lost their lives under the constant bombardment and sniper shooting at civilians by the [Serb forces](/wiki/Army_of_Republika_Srpska "Army of Republika Srpska") during the siege,^[\[59\]](#cite_note-UNCOE-60)^ the longest siege of a capital city in the history of modern warfare.^[\[60\]](#cite_note-61)^ Bosnian Serb forces of the [Republika Srpska](/wiki/Republika_Srpska "Republika Srpska") and the [Yugoslav People's Army](/wiki/Yugoslav_People%27s_Army "Yugoslav People's Army") besieged Sarajevo from 5 April 1992 to 29 February 1996.{#cite_ref-61}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Signing_the_Dayton_Agreement_Milosevic_Tudjman_Izetbegovic.jpg/220px-Signing_the_Dayton_Agreement_Milosevic_Tudjman_Izetbegovic.jpg)](/wiki/File:Signing_the_Dayton_Agreement_Milosevic_Tudjman_Izetbegovic.jpg) The signing of the [Dayton Agreement](/wiki/Dayton_Agreement "Dayton Agreement") in [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") ended the 3 1⁄2-year-long [Bosnian War](/wiki/Bosnian_War "Bosnian War")

When [Bosnia and Herzegovina declared independence](/wiki/1992_Bosnian_independence_referendum "1992 Bosnian independence referendum") from [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia") and achieved [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") recognition, Serbian leaders declared a new Serbian national state Republika Srpska (RS) which was carved out from the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-62)^ The Army of Republika Srpska encircled Sarajevo with a siege force of 18,000^[\[62\]](#cite_note-Times-63)^ stationed in the surrounding hills, from which they assaulted the city with artillery, mortars, tanks, anti-aircraft guns, heavy machine guns, multiple rocket launchers, rocket-launched aircraft bombs, and sniper rifles.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-Times-63)^ From 2 May 1992, the Serbs [blockaded](/wiki/Blockade "Blockade") the city. The [Bosnian government defense forces](/wiki/Army_of_the_Republic_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina") inside the besieged city were poorly equipped and unable to break the siege.{#cite_ref-Times_63-1}

During the siege, 11,541 people were killed, including over 1,500 children. An additional 56,000 people were wounded, including nearly 15,000 children.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-UNCOE-60)^ The [1991 census](/wiki/1991_population_census_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "1991 population census in Bosnia and Herzegovina") indicates that before the siege, the city and its surrounding areas had a population of 525,980.{#cite_ref-UNCOE_60-1}

When the siege ended, the concrete scars caused by mortar shell explosions left marks that were filled with red resin. After the red resin was placed, it left floral patterns, which led to them being dubbed [Sarajevo Roses](/wiki/Sarajevo_Rose "Sarajevo Rose"). Division of the territory according to the [Dayton Agreement](/wiki/Dayton_Agreement "Dayton Agreement") resulted in a [mass exodus](/wiki/Exodus_of_Sarajevo_Serbs "Exodus of Sarajevo Serbs") in early 1996 of some 62,000 Sarajevo Serbs from the city and its suburbs, creating today's more monoethnic post-war city.^[\[63\]](#cite_note-64)^{#cite_ref-64}  

### Present {#Present}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Present")\]  
Main article: [History of modern Sarajevo](/wiki/History_of_modern_Sarajevo "History of modern Sarajevo")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/BBI_Shopping_and_Business_Center.jpg/220px-BBI_Shopping_and_Business_Center.jpg)](/wiki/File:BBI_Shopping_and_Business_Center.jpg) [ARIA Centar](/wiki/ARIA_Centar "ARIA Centar"), erected in 2009

Various modern buildings now occupy Sarajevo's skyline, most significantly the [Bosmal City Center](/wiki/Bosmal_City_Center "Bosmal City Center"), [ARIA Centar](/wiki/ARIA_Centar "ARIA Centar"), [Sarajevo City Center](/wiki/Sarajevo_City_Center "Sarajevo City Center") (all three by architect [Sead Gološ](/wiki/Sead_Golo%C5%A1 "Sead Gološ")) and the [Avaz Twist Tower](/wiki/Avaz_Twist_Tower "Avaz Twist Tower"), which at the time of its building was the tallest skyscraper in former Yugoslavia.

In 2014, the city saw [anti-government protests and riots](/wiki/2014_unrest_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "2014 unrest in Bosnia and Herzegovina") and record rainfall [that caused historic flooding](/wiki/2014_Southeast_Europe_floods "2014 Southeast Europe floods"). Recent years have seen population growth as well as increases in tourism.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-65)^{#cite_ref-65}

The [Sarajevo cable car](/wiki/Sarajevo_cable_car "Sarajevo cable car"), also known as the Trebević cable car, Sarajevo's key landmark during the 1984 Winter Olympics, was rebuilt in 2017 and reopened on 6 April 2018.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-66)^ The cable car runs from Sarajevo at Bistrik station to the slopes of [Trebević](/wiki/Trebevi%C4%87 "Trebević") at Vidikovac station.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-67)^{#cite_ref-67}  

Administration {#Administration}
--------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Administration")\]  

### Largest city of Bosnia and Herzegovina {#Largest_city_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Largest city of Bosnia and Herzegovina")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Presidency_of_BiH_in_Sarajevo_2023.01.29_1.jpg/220px-Presidency_of_BiH_in_Sarajevo_2023.01.29_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Presidency_of_BiH_in_Sarajevo_2023.01.29_1.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/Parliament_%286042784223%29.jpg/248px-Parliament_%286042784223%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Parliament_(6042784223).jpg)  
The [Building of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Building_of_the_Presidency_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Building of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina") (left) and Bosnia and Herzegovina's [government building](/wiki/Greece%E2%80%93Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_Friendship_Building "Greece–Bosnia and Herzegovina Friendship Building") (right)

Sarajevo is the capital^[\[67\]](#cite_note-68)^ of the country of [Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina") and its sub-entity, the [Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Federation_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina"), as well as of the [Sarajevo Canton](/wiki/Sarajevo_Canton "Sarajevo Canton"). It is also the *de jure* capital of another entity, [Republika Srpska](/wiki/Republika_Srpska "Republika Srpska").^[\[68\]](#cite_note-69)^ Each of these levels of government has its parliament or council, as well as judicial courts, in the city. All national institutions and foreign [embassies](/wiki/Diplomatic_mission "Diplomatic mission") are in Sarajevo.{#cite_ref-69}

Sarajevo is home to the [Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina"), [Parliamentary Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Parliamentary_Assembly_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Parliamentary Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina"), [Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Presidency_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina"), the [Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina") and the operational command of the [Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina").^[\[69\]](#cite_note-70)^{#cite_ref-70}

Bosnia and Herzegovina's [Parliament office](/wiki/Greece%E2%80%93Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_Friendship_Building "Greece–Bosnia and Herzegovina Friendship Building") in Sarajevo was damaged heavily in the [Bosnian War](/wiki/Bosnian_War "Bosnian War"). Due to damage, the staff and documents were moved to a nearby ground-level office to resume work. In late 2006, reconstruction work started on Parliament and was finished in 2007. The cost of reconstruction was 80% funded by the [Greek Government](/wiki/Politics_of_Greece "Politics of Greece") through the Hellenic Program of Balkans Reconstruction (ESOAV), and 20% by Bosnia and Herzegovina.  

### Municipalities and city government {#Municipalities_and_city_government}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Municipalities and city government")\]  
Main articles: [List of mayors of Sarajevo](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Sarajevo "List of mayors of Sarajevo") and [Sarajevo City Council](/wiki/Sarajevo_City_Council "Sarajevo City Council")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Sarajevo_municipalities.PNG/200px-Sarajevo_municipalities.PNG)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_municipalities.PNG) The four municipalities of the City of Sarajevo ([Novi Grad](/wiki/Novi_Grad,_Sarajevo "Novi Grad, Sarajevo"), [Novo Sarajevo](/wiki/Novo_Sarajevo "Novo Sarajevo"), [Centar](/wiki/Centar,_Sarajevo "Centar, Sarajevo") and [Stari Grad](/wiki/Stari_Grad,_Sarajevo "Stari Grad, Sarajevo")) within the territory of [Sarajevo Canton](/wiki/Sarajevo_Canton "Sarajevo Canton")

The City of Sarajevo comprises four municipalities: [Centar](/wiki/Centar,_Sarajevo "Centar, Sarajevo"), [Novi Grad](/wiki/Novi_Grad,_Sarajevo "Novi Grad, Sarajevo"), [Novo Sarajevo](/wiki/Novo_Sarajevo "Novo Sarajevo"), and [Stari Grad](/wiki/Stari_Grad,_Sarajevo "Stari Grad, Sarajevo"). Each operates their own [municipal government](/wiki/Local_government "Local government"), while united they form one city government with its constitution. The [executive branch](/wiki/Executive_(government) "Executive (government)") ([Bosnian](/wiki/Bosnian_language "Bosnian language"): *Gradska uprava* ) consists of a [mayor](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Sarajevo "List of mayors of Sarajevo"), with two deputies and a cabinet.

The [legislative branch](/wiki/Legislature "Legislature") consists of the [City Council](/wiki/Sarajevo_City_Council "Sarajevo City Council"), or *Gradsko vijeće* . The council has 28 members, including a council speaker, two deputies, and a secretary. Councilors are elected by the municipality in numbers roughly proportional to their population.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-71)^ The City Statute requires the city council to include at least six councilors from each [constituent people](/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Ethnic groups in Bosnia and Herzegovina") and at least two from the ranks of Others.{#cite_ref-71}

Sarajevo's Municipalities are further split into "local communities" (Bosnian, *Mjesne zajednice*). Local communities have a small role in city government and are intended as a way for ordinary citizens to get involved in city government. They are based on key neighborhoods in the city.  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Economy")\]  
Main article: [Economy of Sarajevo](/wiki/Economy_of_Sarajevo "Economy of Sarajevo")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Sarajevo_Tram-Stop_Banka_2011-10-28_%282%29.jpg/220px-Sarajevo_Tram-Stop_Banka_2011-10-28_%282%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Tram-Stop_Banka_2011-10-28_(2).jpg) Central Bank of Bosnia and Herzegovina

Sarajevo's large manufacturing, administrative, and tourism sectors make it the strongest economic region of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Sarajevo Canton generates almost 25% of the country's GDP.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-72)^ After years of war, Sarajevo's economy saw reconstruction and rehabilitation programs.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-73)^ The [Central Bank of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Central Bank of Bosnia and Herzegovina") opened in Sarajevo in 1997 and the [Sarajevo Stock Exchange](/wiki/Sarajevo_Stock_Exchange "Sarajevo Stock Exchange") began trading in 2002.{#cite_ref-73}

While Sarajevo had a large industrial base during its communist period, only a few pre-existing businesses have successfully adapted to the [market economy](/wiki/Market_economy "Market economy"). Sarajevo industries now include tobacco products, furniture, hosiery, automobiles, and communication equipment.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-Brit-42)^ Companies based in Sarajevo include [BH Telecom](/wiki/BH_Telecom "BH Telecom"), [Bosnalijek](/wiki/Bosnalijek "Bosnalijek"), [Energopetrol](/wiki/Energopetrol "Energopetrol"), [Sarajevo Tobacco Factory](/wiki/Sarajevo_Tobacco_Factory "Sarajevo Tobacco Factory"), and [Sarajevska pivara](/wiki/Sarajevska_pivara "Sarajevska pivara") (Sarajevo Brewery).{#cite_ref-Brit_42-2}

In 2019, the total export for the Sarajevo Canton was worth about 1,427,496,000 [KM](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_convertible_mark "Bosnia and Herzegovina convertible mark"). Most of Sarajevo's exports (20.55%) head to [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany"), with [Serbia](/wiki/Serbia "Serbia") and [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia") following behind at 12% respectively. The largest amount of imported goods comes from Croatia, at 20.95%. With a worth of total import of about 4,872,213,000 [KM](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_convertible_mark "Bosnia and Herzegovina convertible mark"), the total import is almost 3.4 times the total export.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-fsz_canton_2020-74)^{#cite_ref-fsz_canton_2020_74-0}

In 1981, Sarajevo's GDP per capita was 133% of the Yugoslav average.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-75)^ Gross pay in Sarajevo in March 2023 was [KM](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_konvertibilna_marka "Bosnia and Herzegovina konvertibilna marka") 2,497 or [€](/wiki/Euro "Euro")1,269, while net salary was KM 1,585 or €805, indicating stable growth.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-fsz_canton_2020-74)^{#cite_ref-fsz_canton_2020_74-1}  

Tourism and recreation {#Tourism_and_recreation}
------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Tourism and recreation")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Trebevi%C4%87ka_%C5%BEi%C4%8Dara_2018_06.jpg/220px-Trebevi%C4%87ka_%C5%BEi%C4%8Dara_2018_06.jpg)](/wiki/File:Trebevi%C4%87ka_%C5%BEi%C4%8Dara_2018_06.jpg) [Sarajevo cable car](/wiki/Sarajevo_cable_car "Sarajevo cable car") taking visitors to mount [Trebević](/wiki/Trebevi%C4%87 "Trebević") from the city center

Sarajevo has a wide tourist industry and a fast-expanding service sector thanks to the strong annual growth in tourist arrivals. Sarajevo also benefits from being both a summer and winter destination with continuity in its tourism throughout the year. The travel guide series, *[Lonely Planet](/wiki/Lonely_Planet "Lonely Planet")* named Sarajevo as the 43rd best city in the world,^[\[16\]](#cite_note-Lonely_Planet_2006-17)^ and in December 2009, listed Sarajevo as one of the top ten cities to visit in 2010.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-News.com.au-18)^{#cite_ref-News.com.au_18-1}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Sarajevo_Wilsons-Promenade_2013-10-18_%282%29.jpg/220px-Sarajevo_Wilsons-Promenade_2013-10-18_%282%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Wilsons-Promenade_2013-10-18_(2).jpg) *[Vilsonovo Šetalište](/wiki/Vilsonovo_%C5%A0etali%C5%A1te "Vilsonovo Šetalište")* (Wilson's Promenade) along the [Miljacka](/wiki/Miljacka "Miljacka")

In 2019, 733,259 tourists visited Sarajevo, giving 1,667,545 overnight stays, which was 20% more than in 2018.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-fsz_canton_2020-74)^^[\[75\]](#cite_note-76)^ Sports-related tourism uses the legacy facilities of the [1984 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1984_Winter_Olympics "1984 Winter Olympics"), especially the skiing facilities on the nearby mountains of [Bjelašnica](/wiki/Bjela%C5%A1nica "Bjelašnica"), [Igman](/wiki/Igman "Igman"), [Jahorina](/wiki/Jahorina "Jahorina"), [Trebević](/wiki/Trebevi%C4%87 "Trebević") and [Treskavica](/wiki/Treskavica "Treskavica").{#cite_ref-76}

Sarajevo's 600 years of history, influenced by both Western and Eastern empires, makes it a [tourist attraction](/wiki/Tourist_attraction "Tourist attraction") with splendid variations. The city has hosted travelers for centuries, because it was an important trading center during the [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") and [Austro-Hungarian](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary") empires and because it was a natural stop for many routes between East and West. Examples of popular destinations in Sarajevo include the [Vrelo Bosne](/wiki/Vrelo_Bosne "Vrelo Bosne") park, the [Sarajevo cathedral](/wiki/Sacred_Heart_Cathedral,_Sarajevo "Sacred Heart Cathedral, Sarajevo"), and the [Gazi Husrev-beg Mosque](/wiki/Gazi_Husrev-beg_Mosque "Gazi Husrev-beg Mosque"). Tourism in Sarajevo is chiefly focused on historical, religious, and cultural sites and winter sports.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Bridge_on_Vrelo_Bosne.jpg/220px-Bridge_on_Vrelo_Bosne.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bridge_on_Vrelo_Bosne.jpg) The [spring](/wiki/Vrelo_Bosne "Vrelo Bosne") of the [Bosna river](/wiki/Bosna_(river) "Bosna (river)") is located in [Ilidža](/wiki/Ilid%C5%BEa "Ilidža"), a chief suburb of Sarajevo

There are many parks throughout the city and on the outskirts. A popular activity among locals is street chess, usually played at [Trg Oslobođenja - Alija Izetbegović](/wiki/Trg_Oslobo%C4%91enja_-_Alija_Izetbegovi%C4%87 "Trg Oslobođenja - Alija Izetbegović"). Veliki Park is the largest green area in the center of Sarajevo. It is nestled between [Titova](/wiki/Marshal_Tito_street_(Sarajevo) "Marshal Tito street (Sarajevo)"), [Koševo](/wiki/Ko%C5%A1evo "Koševo"), [Džidžikovac](/wiki/D%C5%BEid%C5%BEikovac "Džidžikovac"), Tina Ujevića and Trampina Streets and in the lower part, there is a monument dedicated to the [Children of Sarajevo](/wiki/Siege_of_Sarajevo#Casualties "Siege of Sarajevo"). [Hastahana](/wiki/Nijaz_Durakovi%C4%87_Park "Nijaz Duraković Park") is a popular place to relax in the Austro-Hungarian neighborhood of [Marijin Dvor](/wiki/Marijin_Dvor_(Sarajevo) "Marijin Dvor (Sarajevo)").^[\[76\]](#cite_note-77)^ [Goat's Bridge](/wiki/Goat%27s_Bridge "Goat's Bridge"), locally known as *Kozija Ćuprija* , in the Miljacka Canyon is also a popular park destination along the [Dariva](/wiki/Goat%27s_Bridge#Dariva "Goat's Bridge") walkway and river Miljacka.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-78)^^[\[78\]](#cite_note-79)^ On 24 December 2012, a park hosting two brass sculptures resembling two mourning mothers was dedicated as the Friendship Park, commemorating over 45 years of friendship between Sarajevo and [Baku](/wiki/Baku "Baku"), the capital of Azerbaijan.{#cite_ref-79}

Sarajevo is also famous for its city lookouts; including an observation deck on the [Avaz Twist Tower](/wiki/Avaz_Twist_Tower "Avaz Twist Tower"), Park Prinčeva restaurant, Vidikovac lookout (Mt. Trebević), Zmajevac lookout and Yellow/White fortresses lookouts (in [Vratnik](/wiki/Vratnik_(Sarajevo) "Vratnik (Sarajevo)")) as well as numerous other rooftops throughout the city (i.e. Alta Shopping Center, [ARIA Centar](/wiki/ARIA_Centar "ARIA Centar"), Hotel Hecco Deluxe). A symbol of Sarajevo is the [Trebević cable car](/wiki/Sarajevo_cable_car "Sarajevo cable car") which was reconstructed in 2018, also it is one of the most popular tourist attractions in the city taking visitors from the city center to Mount Trebević.

There is also a [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") tentative monument, the [Old Jewish Cemetery](/wiki/Old_Jewish_Cemetery,_Sarajevo "Old Jewish Cemetery, Sarajevo"), an almost 500 years old site that is the second-largest Jewish sepulchral complex in Europe, the one in [Prague](/wiki/Prague "Prague") being the largest. It is also one of the most significant memorial complexes in the world. It represents the eternal proof of the coexistence of two or more different confessions under different administrations and rules, and the proof of mutual respect and tolerance.^[\[79\]](#cite_note-auto-80)^{#cite_ref-auto_80-0}

Thanks to steady but constant and stable growth after the war, today's built-up area includes not only previously mentioned urban municipalities but the urban part of [Hadžići](/wiki/Had%C5%BEi%C4%87i "Hadžići") that is uninterruptedly connected to [Ilidža](/wiki/Ilid%C5%BEa "Ilidža"), the westernmost part of the Sarajevo urban settlement, is inhabited by more than 419,000 people, while [the metro area](/wiki/Sarajevo_metropolitan_area "Sarajevo metropolitan area") including 8 additional municipalities, 14 in total goes up to 555,210 inhabitants.^[\[81\]](#cite_note-82)^ It is noticeable that the fastest-growing municipalities are [Novi Grad](/wiki/Novi_Grad,_Sarajevo "Novi Grad, Sarajevo"), one of the main ones and the most inhabited one where the population has increased by almost 4,000 people or 2.95% since the [2013 census](/wiki/2013_population_census_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "2013 population census in Bosnia and Herzegovina"), and Ilidža that has recorded an increase of almost 7% since 2013.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-fsz_canton_2020-74)^{#cite_ref-fsz_canton_2020_74-3}

In June 2016, the final results of the 2013 census were published. According to the census, the population of the [Sarajevo Canton](/wiki/Sarajevo_Canton "Sarajevo Canton") was 413,593, with 55,181 residents in [Centar](/wiki/Centar,_Sarajevo "Centar, Sarajevo"), 118,553 in Novi Grad, 64,814 in [Novo Sarajevo](/wiki/Novo_Sarajevo "Novo Sarajevo") and 36,976 in [Stari Grad](/wiki/Stari_Grad,_Sarajevo "Stari Grad, Sarajevo").^[\[82\]](#cite_note-Popis2013-83)^{#cite_ref-Popis2013_83-0}

The last official Yugoslav census took place in [1991](/wiki/1991_population_census_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "1991 population census in Bosnia and Herzegovina") and recorded 527,049 people living in the city of Sarajevo (ten [municipalities](/wiki/Municipality "Municipality")). In the settlement of Sarajevo proper, there were 454,319 inhabitants.^[\[83\]](#cite_note-84)^^\[*[full citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#What_information_to_include "Wikipedia:Citing sources")*\]^ The war displaced hundreds of thousands of people, a large majority of whom have not returned.{#cite_ref-84}

The war changed the ethnic and religious profile of the city. It had long been a multicultural city,^[\[84\]](#cite_note-85)^ and often went by the nickname of "Europe's Jerusalem".^[\[1\]](#cite_note-In_Europe's_Jerusalem-1)^ At the time of the 1991 census, 49.2 percent of the city's population of 527,049 were [Bosniaks](/wiki/Bosniaks "Bosniaks"), 29.8 percent [Serbs](/wiki/Serbs_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Serbs of Bosnia and Herzegovina"), 10.7 percent [Yugoslavs](/wiki/Yugoslavs "Yugoslavs"), 6.6 percent [Croats](/wiki/Croats_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Croats of Bosnia and Herzegovina") and 3.6 percent other ethnicities (Jews, Romas, etc.).{#cite_ref-In_Europe's_Jerusalem_1-2}

According to academic Fran Markowitz, there are several "administrative apparatuses and public pressures that push people who might prefer to identify as flexible, multiply constituted hybrids or with one of the now unnamed minority groups into one of the three Bosniac-Croat-Serb constituent nations".^[\[85\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarkowitz200757-86)^ These include respondents being encouraged by census interviewers to identify as belonging to one of the three [constituent peoples](/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Ethnic groups in Bosnia and Herzegovina").^[\[86\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarkowitz200769-87)^ Her analysis of marriage registration data shows, for instance, that 67 percent of people marrying in 2003 identified as Bosniak or Muslim, which is significantly lower than the 79.6 percent census figure from 2002 (unlike the census, where people respond to an interviewer, applicants to the marriage registry fill in the form themselves).{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarkowitz200769_87-0}

Transportation {#Transportation}
--------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Transportation")\]  

### Roads and highways {#Roads_and_highways}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Roads and highways")\]

Sarajevo's location in a valley between mountains makes it a compact city. Narrow city streets and a lack of parking areas restrict automobile traffic but allow better pedestrian and cyclist mobility. The two main roads are [Titova Ulica](/wiki/Marshal_Tito_street_(Sarajevo) "Marshal Tito street (Sarajevo)") (Street of [Marshal Tito](/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito "Josip Broz Tito")) and the east--west [Zmaj od Bosne](/wiki/Husein_Grada%C5%A1%C4%8Devi%C4%87 "Husein Gradaščević") (Dragon of Bosnia) highway (E761). Located roughly at the center of the country, Sarajevo is Bosnia's main intersection. The city is connected to all the other major cities by highway or national road like [Zenica](/wiki/Zenica "Zenica"), [Banja Luka](/wiki/Banja_Luka "Banja Luka"), [Tuzla](/wiki/Tuzla "Tuzla"), [Mostar](/wiki/Mostar "Mostar"), [Goražde](/wiki/Gora%C5%BEde "Goražde") and [Foča](/wiki/Fo%C4%8Da "Foča").

Tourists from [Central Europe](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe") and elsewhere visiting [Dalmatia](/wiki/Dalmatia "Dalmatia") driving via [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest "Budapest") through Sarajevo also contribute to the traffic congestion in and around Sarajevo. The trans-European highway, [Corridor Vc](/wiki/European_route_E73 "European route E73"), runs through Sarajevo connecting it to Budapest in the north, and [Ploče](/wiki/Plo%C4%8De "Ploče") at the Adriatic Sea in the south.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-88)^ The highway is being built by the [government](/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina") and should cost 3.5 billion [Euro](/wiki/Euro "Euro"). Up until March 2012, the [Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Federation_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina") invested around 600 million euros in the A1. In 2014, the sections Sarajevo-Zenica and Sarajevo-[Tarčin](/wiki/Tar%C4%8Din "Tarčin") were completed including the [Sarajevo Beltway](/wiki/Sarajevo_Beltway "Sarajevo Beltway") ring road.{#cite_ref-88}  

### Tram, bus and trolleybus {#Tram.2C_bus_and_trolleybus}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Tram, bus and trolleybus")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Sarajevo_Stadler_Tango_NF3_009_May2024_%28cropped%29.JPG/220px-Sarajevo_Stadler_Tango_NF3_009_May2024_%28cropped%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Stadler_Tango_NF3_009_May2024_(cropped).JPG) [Sarajevo tram](/wiki/Trams_in_Sarajevo "Trams in Sarajevo")

[Sarajevo's electric tramways](/wiki/Trams_in_Sarajevo "Trams in Sarajevo"), in operation since 1884 and electrified since 1895, are the oldest form of public transportation in the city.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-89)^ Sarajevo had the first full-time (dawn to dusk) tram line in Europe, and the second in the world.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-amazon1-15)^ Opened on [New Year's Day](/wiki/New_Year%27s_Day "New Year's Day") in 1885, it was the testing line for the tram in [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna") and the [Austro-Hungarian Empire](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary"), and operated by horses. Originally built to 760 mm (
2 ft 5+15⁄16 in) [Bosnian gauge](/wiki/Bosnian_gauge "Bosnian gauge"), the present system in 1960 was upgraded to 1,435 mm (
4 ft 8+1⁄2 in) [standard gauge](/wiki/Standard_gauge "Standard gauge"). The trams played a pivotal role in the growth of the city in the 20th century.{#cite_ref-amazon1_15-1}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Sarajevo_Bus_Centrotrans_Line-Dobrinja-Vijecnica_2011-09-28.jpg/220px-Sarajevo_Bus_Centrotrans_Line-Dobrinja-Vijecnica_2011-09-28.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Bus_Centrotrans_Line-Dobrinja-Vijecnica_2011-09-28.jpg) [MAN](/wiki/MAN_Truck_%26_Bus "MAN Truck & Bus") Centrotrans bus

There are seven tramway lines supplemented by five [trolleybus](/wiki/Trolleybus "Trolleybus") lines and numerous bus routes. The [main railway station](/wiki/Sarajevo_main_railway_station "Sarajevo main railway station") in Sarajevo is in the north-central area of the city. From there, the tracks head west before branching off in different directions, including to industrial zones in the city. Sarajevo is undergoing a major infrastructure renewal; many highways and streets are being repaved, the tram system is undergoing modernization, and new bridges and roads are under construction. In January 2021, the city bought 25 new BKM 433 trolleybuses.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-90)^ [Tram track](/wiki/Tramway_track "Tramway track") renovation lasted from August 2021 to September 2023.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-91)^ The city also bought 15 new [Stadler Tango](/wiki/Stadler_Tango "Stadler Tango") trams in September 2021.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-92)^ The first tram arrived in December 2023, while the rest are expected to arrive by the summer of 2024.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-93)^ An additional 10 new trams were bought, as well as 30 new buses.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-94)^{#cite_ref-94}  

### Railway {#Railway}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Railway")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Sarajevo_Railway-Station_2011-10-01_%283%29.JPG/220px-Sarajevo_Railway-Station_2011-10-01_%283%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Railway-Station_2011-10-01_(3).JPG) [Sarajevo main railway station](/wiki/Sarajevo_main_railway_station "Sarajevo main railway station")

The [Sarajevo main railway station](/wiki/Sarajevo_main_railway_station "Sarajevo main railway station") was built in 1882 for the [narrow-gauge railway](/wiki/Narrow-gauge_railway "Narrow-gauge railway"). After [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), it was decided to replace the old station by a new [functionalist](/wiki/Functionalism_(architecture) "Functionalism (architecture)") building. The ceremonial completion of the station building took place in 1949. The station was electrified in 1967, as part of the early electrification program introduced in Bosnia up to 1969.

The [Sarajevo--Ploče railway](/wiki/Sarajevo%E2%80%93Plo%C4%8De_railway "Sarajevo–Ploče railway") provides a connection to the [Adriatic](/wiki/Adriatic_Sea "Adriatic Sea") coast. It holds the distinction of being the first 25 kV AC-electrified country in the former Yugoslavia, followed by Croatia and Serbia. Once, the [East Bosnian railway](/wiki/Narrow-gauge_railways_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina#East_Bosnian_railway "Narrow-gauge railways in Bosnia and Herzegovina") connected Sarajevo to [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade").  

#### Metro plans {#Metro_plans}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Metro plans")\]

To solve traffic congestion in the city, Sarajevo-based architect Muzafer Osmanagić proposed a study called "Eco Energy 2010--2015", proposing a subway system underneath the bed of the river [Miljacka](/wiki/Miljacka "Miljacka"). The first line of Metro Sarajevo would connect [Baščaršija](/wiki/Ba%C5%A1%C4%8Dar%C5%A1ija "Baščaršija") with [Otoka](/wiki/Otoka,_Sarajevo "Otoka, Sarajevo"). This line would cost some 150 million [KM](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_convertible_mark "Bosnia and Herzegovina convertible mark") and be financed by the [European Bank for Reconstruction and Development](/wiki/European_Bank_for_Reconstruction_and_Development "European Bank for Reconstruction and Development").^[\[94\]](#cite_note-95)^{#cite_ref-95}  

### Airport {#Airport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Airport")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Sarajevo_Airport_1_2024.jpg/220px-Sarajevo_Airport_1_2024.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Airport_1_2024.jpg) [Sarajevo International Airport](/wiki/Sarajevo_International_Airport "Sarajevo International Airport")

[Sarajevo International Airport](/wiki/Sarajevo_International_Airport "Sarajevo International Airport") ([IATA](/wiki/IATA_airport_code "IATA airport code"): **SJJ** ) is just a few kilometers southwest of the city and was voted Best European Airport With Under 1,000,000 Passengers at the 15th Annual ACI-Europe in [Munich](/wiki/Munich "Munich") in 2005.

The first regular flights to Sarajevo using an airfield in the suburb of [Butmir](/wiki/Butmir "Butmir") began in 1930 when the domestic airliner [Aeroput](/wiki/Aeroput "Aeroput") opened a regular route linking [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade") to [Podgorica](/wiki/Podgorica "Podgorica") through Sarajevo.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-aeroput-96)^ Later, Aeroput opened a route that linked Sarajevo with [Split](/wiki/Split,_Croatia "Split, Croatia"), [Rijeka](/wiki/Rijeka "Rijeka"), and [Dubrovnik](/wiki/Dubrovnik "Dubrovnik"), and in 1938, the first international flights were introduced when Aeroput extended the route Dubrovnik -- Sarajevo -- Zagreb to [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"), [Brno](/wiki/Brno "Brno") and [Prague](/wiki/Prague "Prague").^[\[95\]](#cite_note-aeroput-96)^^[\[96\]](#cite_note-97)^ The airfield in Butmir remained in use until 1969.{#cite_ref-97}

The need for a new airport in Sarajevo, with an asphalt-concrete runway, was acknowledged in the mid-1960s when [JAT](/wiki/Jat_Airways "Jat Airways"), the Yugoslav national carrier at that time, began acquiring jet planes. The construction of the airport began in 1966 at its present location, not far from the old one.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-jodogoairportassist.com-98)^{#cite_ref-jodogoairportassist.com_98-0}

Sarajevo Airport opened on 2 June 1969 for domestic traffic. In 1970, [Frankfurt](/wiki/Frankfurt "Frankfurt") became the first international destination served. Most of the time the airport was a 'feeder' airport where passengers embarked for flights to Zagreb and Belgrade on their way to international destinations. Over time, the traffic volume steadily grew from 70,000 to 600,000 passengers a year.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-jodogoairportassist.com-98)^ Later, during the [Bosnian War](/wiki/Bosnian_War "Bosnian War"), the airport was used for [UN](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") flights and humanitarian relief. Since the [Dayton Agreement](/wiki/Dayton_Agreement "Dayton Agreement") in 1995, the airport retook its role as the main air portal to Bosnia and Herzegovina.{#cite_ref-jodogoairportassist.com_98-1}

In 2017, 957,971 passengers travelled through the airport, which was 61,4% of the total airport traffic in Bosnia and Herzegovina.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-sarajevo-airport.ba-99)^^[\[99\]](#cite_note-100)^{#cite_ref-100}

Plans for the extension of the passenger terminal, together with upgrading and expanding the taxiway and apron, started in the fall of 2012. The existing terminal was expanded by approximately 7,000 m^2^ (75,347 sq ft).^[\[100\]](#cite_note-101)^ The upgraded airport was directly linked to the commercial retail center Sarajevo Airport Center, making it easier for tourists and travelers to spend their time before flight boarding shopping and enjoying the many amenities that are offered.^[\[101\]](#cite_note-airportcentersarajevo.com-102)^ Between 2015 and 2018, the airport was upgraded for more than 25 million euros.{#cite_ref-airportcentersarajevo.com_102-0}
