Communications and media {#Communications_and_media}
----------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Communications and media")\]  
Main article: [Communications and media in Sarajevo](/wiki/Communications_and_media_in_Sarajevo "Communications and media in Sarajevo")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Telescope_on_Avaz_Twist_Tower.JPG/160px-Telescope_on_Avaz_Twist_Tower.JPG)](/wiki/File:Telescope_on_Avaz_Twist_Tower.JPG) Observation deck on top of the [Avaz Twist Tower](/wiki/Avaz_Twist_Tower "Avaz Twist Tower")

As the largest city of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Sarajevo is the main center of the country's media. Most of the communications and media infrastructure was destroyed during the war but reconstruction monitored by the [Office of the High Representative](/wiki/High_Representative_for_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "High Representative for Bosnia and Herzegovina") has helped to modernize the industry as a whole.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-107)^ For example, the Internet was first made available to the city in 1995.^[\[107\]](#cite_note-108)^{#cite_ref-108}

*[Oslobođenje](/wiki/Oslobo%C4%91enje "Oslobođenje")* (Liberation), founded in 1943, is Sarajevo's longest-running continuously circulating newspaper and the only one to survive the war. However, this long-running and trusted newspaper has fallen behind *[Dnevni avaz](/wiki/Dnevni_avaz "Dnevni avaz")* (Daily Voice), founded in 1995, and *Jutarnje Novine* (Morning News) in circulation in Sarajevo.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-109)^ Other local periodicals include the Croatian newspaper *[Hrvatska riječ](/wiki/Hrvatska_rije%C4%8D "Hrvatska riječ")* and the Bosnian magazine *[Start](/w/index.php?title=Start_(Bosnian_magazine)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Start (Bosnian magazine) (page does not exist)")* , as well as weekly newspapers *[Slobodna Bosna](/wiki/Slobodna_Bosna "Slobodna Bosna")* (*Free Bosnia* ) and *BH Dani* (*BH Days* ). *[Novi Plamen](/wiki/Novi_Plamen "Novi Plamen")*, a monthly magazine, is the most left-wing publication.{#cite_ref-109}

The [Radio and Television of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Radio_and_Television_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Radio and Television of Bosnia and Herzegovina") (BHRT) is Sarajevo's [public television](/wiki/Public_broadcasting "Public broadcasting") station and was created in 1945 under the umbrella of the [Yugoslav Radio Television](/wiki/Yugoslav_Radio_Television "Yugoslav Radio Television") (JRT). It had its first television program aired in 1961, while continuous programming started in 1969. It is one of three main TV stations in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Other stations based in the city include [Hayat TV](/wiki/Hayat_TV_(Bosnia_and_Herzegovina) "Hayat TV (Bosnia and Herzegovina)"), [O Kanal](/wiki/O_Kanal "O Kanal"), [OBN](/wiki/OBN_(TV_channel) "OBN (TV channel)"), [TV Kantona Sarajevo](/wiki/TVSA "TVSA") and [TV Alfa](/wiki/TV_Alfa "TV Alfa").

The headquarters of [Al Jazeera Balkans](/wiki/Al_Jazeera_Balkans "Al Jazeera Balkans") is also in Sarajevo, with a broadcasting studio at the top of the [ARIA Centar](/wiki/ARIA_Centar "ARIA Centar"). The news channel covers [Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina"), [Serbia](/wiki/Serbia "Serbia"), [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia") and [Montenegro](/wiki/Montenegro "Montenegro") and the surrounding [Balkan](/wiki/Balkans "Balkans") states.^[\[109\]](#cite_note-110)^{#cite_ref-110}

Many small independent radio stations exist, including established stations such as [Radio M](/wiki/Radio_M "Radio M"), [RSG Radio](/wiki/RSG_Radio "RSG Radio") (Radio Old Town), Studentski eFM Radio,^[\[110\]](#cite_note-111)^ Radio 202 and [Radio BIR](/wiki/Radio_BIR "Radio BIR").^[\[111\]](#cite_note-112)^ [Radio Free Europe](/wiki/Radio_Free_Europe/Radio_Liberty "Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty"), as well as several American and Western European stations are available.{#cite_ref-112}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Education")\]  

### Higher education {#Higher_education}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Higher education")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Sarajevo_University_building.JPG/220px-Sarajevo_University_building.JPG)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_University_building.JPG) Rectorate and the [Faculty of Law](/wiki/Faculty_of_Law,_University_of_Sarajevo "Faculty of Law, University of Sarajevo"), [University of Sarajevo](/wiki/University_of_Sarajevo "University of Sarajevo") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Sarajevo_City_Hall_Vijecnica_%2823242695334%29.jpg/220px-Sarajevo_City_Hall_Vijecnica_%2823242695334%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_City_Hall_Vijecnica_(23242695334).jpg) [National and University Library of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/National_and_University_Library_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "National and University Library of Bosnia and Herzegovina")

Higher education has a long and rich tradition in Sarajevo. The first institution that can be classified as a tertiary educational institution was a school of [Sufi](/wiki/Sufism "Sufism") philosophy established by [Gazi Husrev-beg](/wiki/Gazi_Husrev-beg "Gazi Husrev-beg") in 1537; numerous other religious schools have been established over time. In 1887, under the Austro-Hungarian Empire, a [Sharia](/wiki/Sharia "Sharia") Law School began a five-year program.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-113)^ In the 1940s, the [University of Sarajevo](/wiki/University_of_Sarajevo "University of Sarajevo") became the city's first secular higher education institute, effectively building upon the foundations established by the Saraybosna Hanıka in 1537. In the 1950s, post-bachelor graduate degrees became available.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-114)^ Severely damaged during the war, it was recently rebuilt in partnership with more than 40 other universities.{#cite_ref-114}

There are also several universities in Sarajevo, including:

* [University of Sarajevo](/wiki/University_of_Sarajevo "University of Sarajevo")
* [Sarajevo School of Science and Technology](/wiki/Sarajevo_School_of_Science_and_Technology "Sarajevo School of Science and Technology")
* [International University of Sarajevo](/wiki/International_University_of_Sarajevo "International University of Sarajevo")
* [Sarajevo Graduate School of Business](/wiki/Sarajevo_Graduate_School_of_Business "Sarajevo Graduate School of Business")
* [International Burch University](/wiki/International_Burch_University "International Burch University")

### Primary and secondary education {#Primary_and_secondary_education}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Primary and secondary education")\]

As of 2005^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit)^, there are 46 elementary schools (Grades 1--9) and 33 high schools (Grades 10--13) in Sarajevo, including three schools for children with special needs.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-115)^{#cite_ref-115}

There are also several [international schools](/wiki/International_school "International school") in Sarajevo, catering to the expatriate community; some of which are [Sarajevo International School](/wiki/Sarajevo_International_School "Sarajevo International School") and the French International School^[\[115\]](#cite_note-116)^ of Sarajevo, established in 1998.{#cite_ref-116}  
Further information: [SBS Sarajevo Business School](/wiki/SBS_Sarajevo_Business_School "SBS Sarajevo Business School")  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Culture")\]  
Main article: [Culture of Sarajevo](/wiki/Culture_of_Sarajevo "Culture of Sarajevo")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Sarajevo_Haggadah.jpg/220px-Sarajevo_Haggadah.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Haggadah.jpg) Copies of the [Sarajevo Haggadah](/wiki/Sarajevo_Haggadah "Sarajevo Haggadah")

Sarajevo has been home to many different religions for centuries, giving the city a range of diverse cultures. In the time of Ottoman occupation of Bosnia, [Muslims](/wiki/Islam "Islam"), [Orthodox Christians](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church"), [Roman Catholics](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church"), and [Sephardi Jews](/wiki/Sephardi_Jews "Sephardi Jews") all shared the city while maintaining distinctive identities. They were joined during the brief occupation by [Austria-Hungary](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary") by a smaller number of [Germans](/wiki/Germans "Germans"), [Hungarians](/wiki/Hungarians "Hungarians"), [Slovaks](/wiki/Slovaks "Slovaks"), [Czechs](/wiki/Czechs "Czechs") and [Ashkenazi Jews](/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews "Ashkenazi Jews"). By 1909, about 50% of the city's inhabitants were Muslim, 25% were Catholic, 15% were Orthodox, and 10% were Jewish.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}

Historically, Sarajevo has been home to several prominent Bosnian poets, scholars, philosophers, and writers. To list only a very few; [Nobel Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize")-winner [Vladimir Prelog](/wiki/Vladimir_Prelog "Vladimir Prelog") is from the city, as are the writer [Zlatko Topčić](/wiki/Zlatko_Top%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Zlatko Topčić") and the poet [Abdulah Sidran](/wiki/Abdulah_Sidran "Abdulah Sidran"). Nobel Prize-winner [Ivo Andrić](/wiki/Ivo_Andri%C4%87 "Ivo Andrić") attended high school in Sarajevo for two years. [Academy Award](/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy Awards")-winning director [Danis Tanović](/wiki/Danis_Tanovi%C4%87 "Danis Tanović") lives in the city.

The [Sarajevo National Theatre](/wiki/Sarajevo_National_Theatre "Sarajevo National Theatre") is the oldest professional theater in Bosnia and Herzegovina, having been established in 1921.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Sarajevo_Bijela_Tabija_banner.jpg/830px-Sarajevo_Bijela_Tabija_banner.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo_Bijela_Tabija_banner.jpg) A [panoramic](/wiki/Panorama "Panorama") view of the ruined castle of [Bijela Tabija](/wiki/Bijela_Tabija "Bijela Tabija") *"White Bastion"* in the very east of Sarajevo  

### Museums {#Museums}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Museums")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/National_Museum_of_BiH_Aerial.JPG/220px-National_Museum_of_BiH_Aerial.JPG)](/wiki/File:National_Museum_of_BiH_Aerial.JPG) The [National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina") houses many important historical items from Bosnia and Herzegovina

Sarajevo is rich in museums, including the [Museum of Sarajevo](/wiki/Museum_of_Sarajevo_1878%E2%80%931918 "Museum of Sarajevo 1878–1918"), the [Ars Aevi](/wiki/Ars_Aevi "Ars Aevi") Museum of Contemporary Art, [Historical Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Historical_Museum_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Historical Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina"), The Museum of Literature and Theatre Arts of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the [National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina") (established in 1888) home to the [Sarajevo Haggadah](/wiki/Sarajevo_Haggadah "Sarajevo Haggadah"),^[\[117\]](#cite_note-118)^ an [illuminated manuscript](/wiki/Illuminated_manuscript "Illuminated manuscript") and the oldest [Sephardic Jewish](/wiki/Sephardi_Jews "Sephardi Jews") document in the world^[\[118\]](#cite_note-119)^ issued in [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona") around 1350, containing the traditional Jewish [Haggadah](/wiki/Haggadah "Haggadah"), is on permanent display at the museum. It is the only remaining illustrated [Sephardic](/wiki/Sephardi_Jews "Sephardi Jews") [Haggadah](/wiki/Sarajevo_Haggadah "Sarajevo Haggadah") in the world.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-120)^ The National Museum also hosts year-round exhibitions about local, regional and international culture and history, and exhibits over 5,000 artifacts from Bosnia's history.{#cite_ref-120}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/MuzejSarajevo1878-1918.JPG/175px-MuzejSarajevo1878-1918.JPG)](/wiki/File:MuzejSarajevo1878-1918.JPG) The [Museum of Sarajevo 1878--1918](/wiki/Museum_of_Sarajevo_1878%E2%80%931918 "Museum of Sarajevo 1878–1918")

The [Alija Izetbegović](/wiki/Alija_Izetbegovi%C4%87 "Alija Izetbegović") Museum was opened on 19 October 2007 and is in the old town fort, more specifically in the [Vratnik](/wiki/Vratnik_(Sarajevo) "Vratnik (Sarajevo)") Kapija towers Ploča and Širokac. The museum is a commemoration of the influence and body of work of Alija Izetbegović, the first [president of the Presidency](/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Presidency_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Chairman of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina") of the [Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Republic_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina"). Sarajevo is also home to the [War Childhood Museum](/wiki/War_Childhood_Museum "War Childhood Museum"), an independent not-for-profit museum containing personal belongings from the war and showing stories behind them. In addition, in 2018, the museum won the [Council of Europe Museum Prize award](/wiki/European_Museum_of_the_Year_Award#Council_of_Europe_Museum_Prize_winners_(1977–) "European Museum of the Year Award") for best museum.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-121)^{#cite_ref-121}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Sarajevo%2C_Ba%C5%A1%C4%8Dar%C5%A1ija_II.jpg/220px-Sarajevo%2C_Ba%C5%A1%C4%8Dar%C5%A1ija_II.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sarajevo,_Ba%C5%A1%C4%8Dar%C5%A1ija_II.jpg) The [Bosniak Institute](/wiki/Bosniak_Institute "Bosniak Institute"), containing collections of the history of [Bosniaks](/wiki/Bosniaks "Bosniaks")

The city also hosts the [Sarajevo National Theatre](/wiki/Sarajevo_National_Theatre "Sarajevo National Theatre"), established in 1921, and the [Sarajevo Youth Theatre](/wiki/Sarajevo_Youth_Theatre "Sarajevo Youth Theatre"). Some other [cultural institutions](/wiki/Cultural_institution "Cultural institution") include the Center for Sarajevo Culture, [Sarajevo City Library](/wiki/National_and_University_Library_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "National and University Library of Bosnia and Herzegovina"), [National Gallery of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "National Gallery of Bosnia and Herzegovina"), and the [Bosniak Institute](/wiki/Bosniak_Institute "Bosniak Institute"), a privately owned library and art collection focusing on Bosniak history.

Demolitions associated with the war, as well as reconstruction, destroyed several institutions and cultural or [religious symbols](/wiki/Religious_symbol "Religious symbol") including the [Gazi Husrev-beg Library](/wiki/Gazi_Husrev-beg_Library "Gazi Husrev-beg Library"), the national library, the [Sarajevo Oriental Institute](/wiki/Oriental_Institute_in_Sarajevo "Oriental Institute in Sarajevo"), and a museum dedicated to the [1984 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1984_Winter_Olympics "1984 Winter Olympics"). Consequently, the different levels of government established strong cultural protection laws and institutions.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-122)^ Bodies charged with cultural preservation in Sarajevo include the Institute for the Protection of the Cultural, Historical and [Natural Heritage](/wiki/Cultural_heritage "Cultural heritage") of Bosnia and Herzegovina (and their Sarajevo Canton counterpart), and the Bosnia and Herzegovina Commission to Preserve National Monuments.{#cite_ref-122}  

### Music {#Music}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Music")\]  
See also: [List of Bosnia and Herzegovina patriotic songs](/wiki/List_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_patriotic_songs "List of Bosnia and Herzegovina patriotic songs")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Tifa_i_Bregovic_Nis_polovina_80-ih.jpg/220px-Tifa_i_Bregovic_Nis_polovina_80-ih.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tifa_i_Bregovic_Nis_polovina_80-ih.jpg) [Bijelo Dugme](/wiki/Bijelo_Dugme "Bijelo Dugme"), widely considered to have been the most popular band ever to exist in the former [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia") and one of the most important acts of the [Yugoslav rock scene](/wiki/Popular_music_in_Yugoslavia "Popular music in Yugoslavia"), originated in Sarajevo. Pictured are [Mladen Vojičić Tifa](/wiki/Mladen_Voji%C4%8Di%C4%87_Tifa "Mladen Vojičić Tifa") (left) and [Goran Bregović](/wiki/Goran_Bregovi%C4%87 "Goran Bregović")

Sarajevo is and has historically been one of the most important musical enclaves in the region. The Sarajevo school of [pop rock](/wiki/Pop_rock "Pop rock") developed in the city between 1961 and 1991. This type of music began with bands like [Indexi](/wiki/Indexi "Indexi"), [Kodeksi](/wiki/Kodeksi "Kodeksi"), and singer-songwriter [Kemal Monteno](/wiki/Kemal_Monteno "Kemal Monteno"). It continued into the 1980s, with bands such as [Plavi orkestar](/wiki/Plavi_orkestar "Plavi orkestar"), [Crvena jabuka](/wiki/Crvena_jabuka "Crvena jabuka"), and [Divlje jagode](/wiki/Divlje_jagode "Divlje jagode"), by most accounts, pioneering the [regional](/wiki/Balkans "Balkans") rock and roll movement. Sarajevo was also the home and birthplace of arguably the most popular and influential Yugoslav [rock band](/wiki/Band_(rock_and_pop) "Band (rock and pop)") of all time, [Bijelo Dugme](/wiki/Bijelo_Dugme "Bijelo Dugme"), somewhat of a Bosnian parallel to the [Rolling Stones](/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones "The Rolling Stones"), in both popularity and influence.

Sarajevo was also the home of a very notable [post-punk](/wiki/Post-punk "Post-punk") urban subculture known as the [New Primitives](/wiki/New_Primitivism "New Primitivism"), which began during the early 1980s with the Baglama Band which was banned shortly after its first LP and was brought into the mainstream through bands such as [Zabranjeno Pušenje](/wiki/Zabranjeno_Pu%C5%A1enje "Zabranjeno Pušenje") and [Elvis J. Kurtović \& His Meteors](/wiki/Elvis_J._Kurtovi%C4%87_%26_His_Meteors "Elvis J. Kurtović & His Meteors"), as well as the *[Top lista nadrealista](/wiki/Top_lista_nadrealista "Top lista nadrealista")* radio, and later television show. Other notable bands considered to be part of this subculture are [Bombaj Štampa](/wiki/Bombaj_%C5%A0tampa "Bombaj Štampa"). Besides and separately from the New Primitives, Sarajevo is the hometown to one of the most significant [ex-Yugoslavian](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia") alternative [industrial](/wiki/Industrial_music "Industrial music")-[noise](/wiki/Noise_music "Noise music") bands, [SCH](/wiki/SCH_(band) "SCH (band)").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Evstafiev-bosnia-cello.jpg/220px-Evstafiev-bosnia-cello.jpg)](/wiki/File:Evstafiev-bosnia-cello.jpg) [Vedran Smailović](/wiki/Vedran_Smailovi%C4%87 "Vedran Smailović") playing the cello on top of the ruins of the [National library](/wiki/National_and_University_Library_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "National and University Library of Bosnia and Herzegovina") in 1992

Perhaps more importantly, Sarajevo in the late 19th and throughout the 20th century was home to a burgeoning and large center of [Sevdalinka](/wiki/Sevdalinka "Sevdalinka") record-making and contributed greatly to bringing this historical genre of music to the mainstream, which had for many centuries been a staple of Bosnian culture. Songwriters and musicians such as [Himzo Polovina](/wiki/Himzo_Polovina "Himzo Polovina"), [Safet Isović](/wiki/Safet_Isovi%C4%87 "Safet Isović"), [Zaim Imamović](/wiki/Zaim_Imamovi%C4%87_(musician) "Zaim Imamović (musician)"), [Zehra Deović](/wiki/Zehra_Deovi%C4%87 "Zehra Deović"), [Halid Bešlić](/wiki/Halid_Be%C5%A1li%C4%87 "Halid Bešlić"), [Hanka Paldum](/wiki/Hanka_Paldum "Hanka Paldum"), [Nada Mamula](/wiki/Nada_Mamula "Nada Mamula"), [Meho Puzić](/wiki/Meho_Puzi%C4%87 "Meho Puzić") and many more composed and wrote some of their most important pieces in the city. Sarajevo also greatly influenced the pop scene of Yugoslavia with musicians like [Zdravko Čolić](/wiki/Zdravko_%C4%8Coli%C4%87 "Zdravko Čolić"), Kemal Monteno, [Dino Merlin](/wiki/Dino_Merlin "Dino Merlin"), [Seid Memić Vajta](/wiki/Seid_Memi%C4%87_Vajta "Seid Memić Vajta"), [Hari Mata Hari](/wiki/Hari_Mata_Hari "Hari Mata Hari"), [Mladen Vojičić Tifa](/wiki/Mladen_Voji%C4%8Di%C4%87_Tifa "Mladen Vojičić Tifa"), [Željko Bebek](/wiki/%C5%BDeljko_Bebek "Željko Bebek") and many more.

Many newer Sarajevo-based bands have also found a name and established themselves in Sarajevo, such as [Regina](/wiki/Regina_(Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_band) "Regina (Bosnia and Herzegovina band)") who also had two albums out in Yugoslavia, and Letu Štuke, who actually formed their band in Yugoslavia with the famous Bosnian-American writer [Aleksandar Hemon](/wiki/Aleksandar_Hemon "Aleksandar Hemon") and got their real breakthrough later in the 2000s. Sarajevo is now home to an important and eclectic mix of new bands and independent musicians, which continue to thrive with the ever-increasing number of festivals, creative showcases, and concerts around the country. The city is also home to the region's largest jazz festival, the [Jazz Fest Sarajevo](/wiki/Jazz_Fest_Sarajevo "Jazz Fest Sarajevo").

American heavy metal band [Savatage](/wiki/Savatage "Savatage"), released a song entitled "[Christmas Eve (Sarajevo 12/24)](/wiki/Christmas_Eve/Sarajevo_12/24 "Christmas Eve/Sarajevo 12/24")" on their 1995 album *[Dead Winter Dead](/wiki/Dead_Winter_Dead "Dead Winter Dead")* , which was about a [cello](/wiki/Cello "Cello") player playing a forgotten [Christmas carol](/wiki/Christmas_carol "Christmas carol") in war-torn Sarajevo. The song was later re-released by the same band under the name [Trans-Siberian Orchestra](/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Orchestra "Trans-Siberian Orchestra") on their 1996 debut album *[Christmas Eve and Other Stories](/wiki/Christmas_Eve_and_Other_Stories "Christmas Eve and Other Stories")*, which the song gave them instant success.  

### Festivals {#Festivals}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Festivals")\]  
See also: [List of festivals in Sarajevo](/wiki/List_of_festivals_in_Sarajevo "List of festivals in Sarajevo")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Sff_20_aug_2014_12.jpg/220px-Sff_20_aug_2014_12.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sff_20_aug_2014_12.jpg) The [Sarajevo Film Festival](/wiki/Sarajevo_Film_Festival "Sarajevo Film Festival") has been held annually since 1995 at the [National Theatre](/wiki/Sarajevo_National_Theatre "Sarajevo National Theatre")

Sarajevo is internationally renowned for its eclectic and diverse selection of over 50 annual festivals. The [Sarajevo Film Festival](/wiki/Sarajevo_Film_Festival "Sarajevo Film Festival") was established in 1995 during the [Bosnian War](/wiki/Bosnian_War "Bosnian War") and has become the premier and largest film festival in [Southeast Europe](/wiki/Southeast_Europe "Southeast Europe").^[\[122\]](#cite_note-About_the_Festival-123)^ It has been hosted at the [National Theater](/wiki/Sarajevo_National_Theatre "Sarajevo National Theatre"), with screenings at the Open-air theater Metalac and the [Bosnian Cultural Center](/wiki/Bosnian_Cultural_Center "Bosnian Cultural Center"), all in downtown Sarajevo. The [MESS International Festival](/wiki/MESS_(festival) "MESS (festival)") is an experimental theatre festival and the oldest living theatre festival in the Balkans.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-124)^ The annual [Sarajevo Youth Film Festival](/wiki/Sarajevo_Youth_Film_Festival "Sarajevo Youth Film Festival") showcases feature, animated and short films from around the world and is the premier student film festival in the Balkans.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-125)^ The [Sarajevo Winter Festival](/wiki/Sarajevo_Winter_Festival "Sarajevo Winter Festival"), [Jazz Fest Sarajevo](/wiki/Jazz_Fest_Sarajevo "Jazz Fest Sarajevo") and Sarajevo International Music Festival are well-known, as is the [Baščaršija Nights](/wiki/Ba%C5%A1%C4%8Dar%C5%A1ija_Nights "Baščaršija Nights") festival, a month-long showcase of local culture, music, and dance.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-125}

The first incarnation of the Sarajevo Film Festival was hosted in still-warring Sarajevo in 1995, and has now progressed into being the biggest and most significant festival in Southeast Europe.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-About_the_Festival-123)^ A talent campus is also held during the duration of the festival, with lecturers speaking on behalf of world cinematography and holding workshops for film students from across Southeast Europe.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-126)^{#cite_ref-126}

The [Jazz Fest Sarajevo](/wiki/Jazz_Fest_Sarajevo "Jazz Fest Sarajevo") is the region's largest and most diverse of its kind. The festival takes place at the [Bosnian Cultural Center](/wiki/Bosnian_Cultural_Center "Bosnian Cultural Center") (aka "Main Stage"), just down the street from the SFF, at the Sarajevo Youth Stage Theater (aka "Strange Fruits Stage"), at the [Dom Vojske Federacije](/wiki/Army_Hall_(Sarajevo) "Army Hall (Sarajevo)") (aka "Solo Stage"), and at the CDA (aka "Groove Stage").  

### Sports {#Sports}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sarajevo&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Sports")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/20150331_2026_AUT_BIH_2177_Edin_D%C5%BEeko.jpg/150px-20150331_2026_AUT_BIH_2177_Edin_D%C5%BEeko.jpg)](/wiki/File:20150331_2026_AUT_BIH_2177_Edin_D%C5%BEeko.jpg) Bosnian [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") player [Edin Džeko](/wiki/Edin_D%C5%BEeko "Edin Džeko") was born in Sarajevo. He is the all-time [leading goalscorer](/wiki/List_of_international_goals_scored_by_Edin_D%C5%BEeko "List of international goals scored by Edin Džeko") of the [Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_national_football_team "Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team")^[\[126\]](#cite_note-FIFA.com:_Edin_DZEKO_Profile-127)^^[\[127\]](#cite_note-128)^ [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Asim_Ferhatovi%C4%87_Hase_Stadium.jpg/200px-Asim_Ferhatovi%C4%87_Hase_Stadium.jpg)](/wiki/File:Asim_Ferhatovi%C4%87_Hase_Stadium.jpg) [Koševo City Stadium](/wiki/Ko%C5%A1evo_City_Stadium "Koševo City Stadium"), home to [FK Sarajevo](/wiki/FK_Sarajevo "FK Sarajevo"), is the largest stadium in Bosnia and Herzegovina^[\[128\]](#cite_note-129)^

Sarajevo hosted the [1984 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1984_Winter_Olympics "1984 Winter Olympics"). Yugoslavia won one medal, a silver in men's giant slalom awarded to [Jure Franko](/wiki/Jure_Franko "Jure Franko").^[\[129\]](#cite_note-130)^ Many of the Olympic facilities survived the war or were reconstructed, including the [Zetra Olympic Hall](/wiki/Zetra_Olympic_Hall,_Sarajevo "Zetra Olympic Hall, Sarajevo") and [Asim Ferhatović Stadium](/wiki/Ko%C5%A1evo_City_Stadium "Koševo City Stadium"). In an attempt to bring back some of Sarajevo's Olympic glory,^[\[130\]](#cite_note-131)^ the original Olympic luge and bobsled tracks are being repaired, due to the efforts of both the [Olympic Committee of Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Olympic_Committee_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Olympic Committee of Bosnia and Herzegovina")^[\[131\]](#cite_note-132)^ and local sports enthusiasts.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-133)^{#cite_ref-133}

After co-hosting the Southeast Europe Friendship games, Sarajevo was awarded the 2009 [Special Olympic](/wiki/Special_Olympics "Special Olympics") winter games,^[\[133\]](#cite_note-134)^ but canceled these plans.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-135)^^[\[135\]](#cite_note-136)^ The ice arena for the 1984 Olympics, Zetra Stadium, was used during the war as a temporary hospital and, later, for housing [NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO") troops of the [IFOR](/wiki/Implementation_Force "Implementation Force").{#cite_ref-136}

In 2011, Sarajevo was the host city of the 51st World Military Skiing Championship with over 350 participants from 23 different nations. This was the first international event of such standing since the 1984 Olympics.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-137)^ [Football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") is popular in Sarajevo; the city hosts [FK Sarajevo](/wiki/FK_Sarajevo "FK Sarajevo") and [FK Željezničar](/wiki/FK_%C5%BDeljezni%C4%8Dar_Sarajevo "FK Željezničar Sarajevo"), which both compete in European and international cups and tournaments and have a very large trophy cabinet in the former Yugoslavia as well as independent Bosnia and Herzegovina. Other notable football clubs include [Olimpik](/wiki/FK_Olimpik "FK Olimpik"), [SAŠK](/wiki/NK_SA%C5%A0K_Napredak "NK SAŠK Napredak") and [Slavija](/wiki/FK_Slavija_Sarajevo "FK Slavija Sarajevo"). One of only three stadiums in Bosnia and Herzegovina that has the [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") category 3 is the [Grbavica Stadium](/wiki/Stadion_Grbavica "Stadion Grbavica"), the home stadium of Željezničar.{#cite_ref-137}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Skenderija_Arena_2018.jpg/200px-Skenderija_Arena_2018.jpg)](/wiki/File:Skenderija_Arena_2018.jpg) [Mirza Delibašić Hall](/wiki/Mirza_Deliba%C5%A1i%C4%87_Hall "Mirza Delibašić Hall"), home venue of past European champion [KK Bosna](/wiki/KK_Bosna_Meridianbet "KK Bosna Meridianbet")

Another popular sport is basketball; the basketball club [KK Bosna](/wiki/KK_Bosna_Meridianbet "KK Bosna Meridianbet") won the [European Championship](/wiki/Euroleague_Basketball "Euroleague Basketball") in 1979 as well as many Yugoslav and Bosnian national championships, making it one of the greatest basketball clubs in the former Yugoslavia. The chess club, [Bosna Sarajevo](/wiki/%C5%A0K_Bosna "ŠK Bosna"), has been a championship team since the 1980s and is the third-ranked chess club in Europe, having won four consecutive European championships in the nineties. Handball club [RK Bosna](/wiki/RK_Bosna_Sarajevo "RK Bosna Sarajevo") also competes in the European Champions League and is considered one of the most well-organized handball clubs in Southeast Europe with a very large [fan base](/wiki/Fan_(person) "Fan (person)") and excellent national, as well as international results. Sarajevo often holds international events and competitions in sports such as [tennis](/wiki/Tennis "Tennis") and [kickboxing](/wiki/Kickboxing "Kickboxing").

The popularity of tennis has been picking up in recent years. Since 2003, [BH Telecom Indoors](/wiki/BH_Telecom_Indoors "BH Telecom Indoors") has been an annual tennis tournament in Sarajevo.

Since 2007, the [Sarajevo Half Marathon](/wiki/Sarajevo_Half_Marathon "Sarajevo Half Marathon") has been organized every year in late September. *Giro di Sarajevo* is also a run in the city with over 2,200 cyclists taking part in 2015.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-138)^{#cite_ref-138}

In February 2019, Sarajevo and [East Sarajevo](/wiki/Isto%C4%8Dno_Sarajevo "Istočno Sarajevo") hosted the [European Youth Olympic Winter Festival](/wiki/2019_European_Youth_Olympic_Winter_Festival "2019 European Youth Olympic Winter Festival") (EYOWF).
